revision.text:
{{Infobox international baseball tournament | country = Venezuela | dates = October 27 – November 18 | num_teams = 6 | continents = 2 | venues = 1 | cities = 1 | defending_champion = Venezuela | prev_year = 1944 | medal_type = world cup | champion = Venezuela | num_championships = 3 | second = Colombia | third = Panama | fourth = Nicaragua | games = 20 | mvp = [[Héctor Benítez]] | prev_edition = [[1944 Amateur World Series|1944]] | next_edition = [[1947 Amateur World Series|1947]] }}
The '''1945 Amateur World Series''' was the eighth edition of the tournament, later known as the [[Baseball World Cup]]. It was contested by six different teams playing ten games each from October 27 through November 18 in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]].
Both [[Cuban national baseball team|Cuba]] and [[Mexican national baseball team| Mexico]] [[boycott]]ed the Series in protest of the events of the [[1944 Amateur World Series|previous edition]], when controversy surrounded the tournament regarding umpiring decisions, which had led to forfeits of games and general ill-will.
The host Venezuelan team finished undefeated with a perfect 10–0 record, winning its second consecutive gold medal and third overall.
[[Colombia national baseball team|Colombia]] finished in second place with a 7–3 record and won silver for its first medal in series history, while [[Panama national baseball team|Panama]] went 6–4 for a bronze medal. It was also the first medal for the Panamanians in the tournament.
[[Nicaragua national baseball team|Nicaragua]], a former silver medalist both in [[1939 Amateur World Series|1939]] and [[1940 Amateur World Series|1940]], placed fourth at 5–5. The [[Costa Rica national baseball team|Costa Rica]] and [[El Salvador national baseball team|El Salvador]] teams debuted in the Series and shared last place with a 1–9 mark.
[[Héctor Benítez]] of Venezuela earned [[Most Valuable Player]] honors after leading the hitter in batting average (.526), hits (20), RBI (16) and runs scored (16). Teammate [[Luis Zuloaga]] was the top pitcher with a 4–0 record, while setting a Series record with seven consecutive wins. Other statistical leaders for Venezuela were [[Ramón Fernández (baseball)|Ramón Fernández]], with 21 hits, and [[Luis Romero Petit]], who stole nine bases.
Another well observed performance came from Panamanian catcher [[León Kellman]], who was the only player to hit two home runs in the Series. Previously, in [[1941 Amateur World Series|1941]], Kellman was the only player to homer in the Series.
==Final standings== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Team ! W ! L |- | {{Bb|Venezuela|1930}} |  10 |  0  |- | {{Bb|Colombia}} |   7 |  3  |- | {{Bb|Panama}} |   6 |  4  |- | {{Bb|Nicaragua}} |   5 |  5  |- | {{Bb|Costa Rica}} |   1 |  9  |- | {{Bb|El Salvador}}     |   1 |  9  |}
==References== * Bjarkman, P. (2007). ''A History of Cuban Baseball, 1864–2006''. McFarland & Company. {{ISBN|978-0-78-642829-8}}. * [http://www.baseball-worldcup.com/worldcup-history/ Baseball World Cup History] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111212001843/http://www.baseballdecuba.com/WCup2011/History.html Historia de la Copa Mundial de Béisbol] (Spanish) {{Baseball World Cup}} [[Category:1945 in baseball|Amateur World Series, 1945]] [[Category:Baseball World Cup]] [[Category:International baseball competitions hosted by Venezuela|1945]] [[Category:1945 in Venezuelan sport]] [[Category:October 1945 sports events]] [[Category:November 1945 sports events]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Caracas]] [[Category:20th century in Caracas]]

{{Infobox building | name = Aguadilla Ice Skating Arena | image = Aguadilla Ice Skating Arena.jpg | location_city = [[Aguadilla, Puerto Rico]] | coordinates = {{coord|18|25|6|N|67|9|23|W| type:landmark_region:US-PR | display=inline,title}} | area = | opening_date = 2005 | owner = City of Aguadilla }} {{refimprove|date=November 2017}} [[File:Aguadilla Ice Skating Arena at night.jpg|right|thumb|275px|At night, AISA is transformed into an ice [[discotheque]].]] '''Aguadilla Ice Skating Arena''', '''A.I.S.A.''', is a multi-use facility in [[Aguadilla, Puerto Rico]]. The [[arena]] is the only [[ice skating]] facility in the [[Caribbean]] region. The facility is owned and administered by the city.
==Brief history== A.I.S.A. opened its doors in 2005 as the only facility of its kind in the Caribbean. Although Puerto Rico hosts several ice skating events during the Christmas season, the AISA is the only ice skating facility open year-round. The arena was designed & fabricated by '''Ice Rink Supply.com''', using their internationally patented technology, for the '''Authority of Municipal Enterprises''' of the city. Aguadilla City Enterprises also administers [[Las Cascadas Water Park]] & Aguadilla Bowling Alley.
==Features== The AISA also hosts numerous stores and establishments:
===First Floor=== * Ice Skating Rink * 1 Dinner Room (soon){{when|date=November 2017}} * 2 Meeting Rooms
===Second Floor=== * Music Room (City Band)
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100516025215/http://www.iihf.com/home-of-hockey/news/news-singleview/article/will-ice-melt-on-puerto-rico.html Will ice melt on Puerto Rico? ]
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Beresford Park | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Ayr]], [[Scotland]] | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position= | latd = | longd = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1884 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1926 | demolished = 1926 | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | tenants = {{infobox stadium/tenantlist | tenant_clubs = [[Ayr F.C.|Ayr FC]]
[[Ayr Parkhouse F.C.|Ayr Parkhouse FC]]
[[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United FC]] Reserves | tenant_years = 1884 – 1888
1888 – 1910
1910 – 1926 }} }} '''Beresford Park''' was a former football stadium in town of [[Ayr]] in [[Scotland]]. The ground was the former home of [[Scottish Football League]] teams [[Ayr F.C.|Ayr FC]] and [[Ayr Parkhouse F.C.|Ayr Parkhouse]] before their merger to form [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United FC]]. The ground was located in the centre of the town, adjacent to [[Robert Burns|Burns]] statue square, where the current [[Odeon Cinemas|Odeon cinema]] stands. Parkhouse street and Beresford Terrace now stand on the former site of the stadium named after [[Ayr Parkhouse F.C.|Ayr Parkhouse FC]], former tenants of the ground and the ground itself respectively. ==Ayr FC== Ayr FC moved to Beresford Park from Springvale Park in 1884 where they stayed until 1888, when they moved to [[Somerset Park]], current home of [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]], taking the grandstand and clubhouse with them.{{cite web | url = http://www.ayrunitedfc.co.uk/about_club_history_somerset_park.asp | title = History of Somerset Park | publisher = Ayr United FC | date = | accessdate = 9 December 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110929190649/http://www.ayrunitedfc.co.uk/about_club_history_somerset_park.asp | archivedate = 29 September 2011 | df = }} Ayr FC moved from Beresford Park as the Annual Ayr Cattle Show, that was hosted at Beresford Park had been booked earlier than usual, clashing with the clubs clash with the [[FA Cup]] holders [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. ==Ayr Parkhouse FC== When Ayr FC moved to Somerset Park, Ayr Parkhouse FC moved from their home at the "''Old Racecourse''" in the [[Seafield, Ayr|Seafield]] area of the town. Ayr Parkhouse FC remained at Beresford Park until the merger with Ayr FC in 1910. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ayr United F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} [[Category:Ayr United F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ayr]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1884]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1926]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in the United Kingdom]]

{{advert|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Bicycling | image_file = Bicycling magazine May 2009.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = May 2009 cover of ''Bicycling'' | editor = Bill Strickland | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = 10 issues annually | total_circulation = 325,000 | circulation_year = 2015 | readership = 2,000,000 | category = | company = [[Hearst Communications|Hearst Magazines]] | publisher = | firstdate = 1961<ref name=rodaletimeline>[http://www.rodaleinc.com/about-us/company-timeline Rodale Company Timeline], retrieved 17 April 2010</ref> | country = United States | based = | language = English | website = [http://www.bicycling.com/ bicycling.com] | issn = 0006-2073 }}
'''''Bicycling''''' is a cycling brand published by [[Hearst Communications|Hearst]] in [[Emmaus, Pennsylvania]]. ''Bicycling'' claims to be the world’s largest cycling magazine. __TOC__
==Origin==
''Bicycling'' started in 1961 as ''Northern California Cycling Association Newsletter'', a 4-page mimeographed newsletter (8 ½ x 14) started by Peter Hoffman. It covered the local bicycle scene and grew quickly as Vol. 1 No. 6 took on a 5 ½ x8 ½ offset printing format in December, 1961. The name was changed to ''American Cycling Newsletter'' with Vol. 3 No. 1 in March, 1964 issue. The name was changed again with Vol. 5 No. 1 in March, 1965 to ''American Cycling''. The size was changed to a larger format with Vol. 5 No. 1 in March, 1966 to 8 ½ x 11. Peter Hoffman sold the magazine to Leete publications in August 1968 but stayed on as an editor until late 1969. The last ''American Cycling'' titled magazine was the Nov. 1968 issue, Vol. 7 No. 8. The name was changed to ''Bicycling!'' with the Dec 1968 Issue Vol 7 No 9. For three months following the name change, "American Cycling" was included on the cover in small print under the ''Bicycling!'' masthead. ''NCCA Newsletter'' and ''American Cycling'' were published 10 times a year, March though December; however, in 1968 -the first year under Leete- there were only 9 issues. Leete skipped the October issue and called it November both to make it more current, and because they were behind in production as they worked on the design change to ''Bicycling!''. After 1968 the magazine went to publishing 12 issues a year. In April 1973 the magazine was acquired by Capital Management Publications. In early December 1977, a team was sent from Rodale to California to meet with the owner and iron out a deal.<ref>Our Roots Grow Deep: The Story of Rodale, Daniel Gross, 2008</ref> Rodale acquired ''Bicycling!'' and published their first issue in February, 1978. In 1980, Rodale purchased a smaller magazine, ''Bike World'', and merged it into ''Bicycling!''. In 1982 Rodale bought ''American Cyclist'' and incorporated it into ''Bicycling''. Pricing of the magazine changed over the years as follows July 62 to December 64, 25 cents, March 65 to June 67, 35 cents, July 67 to July 68, 45 cents, In August 1968 with the Leete purchase the price went up to 50 cents, and the covers were changed to full color, the previous covers had been in red and black.
Hearst acquired Rodale in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcall.com/business/mc-biz-hearst-buys-rodale-20170927-story.html|title=Media giant Hearst will acquire Rodale|last=Wagaman|first=Andrew|date=October 18, 2017|work=[[The Morning Call]]|access-date=2017-10-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/hearst-agrees-to-acquire-rodale-inc-publisher-of-mens-health-and-runners-world-1508361381|title=Hearst Agrees to Acquire Rodale Inc., Publisher of Men’s Health and Runner’s World|last=Trachtenberg|first=Jeffrey A.|date=2017-10-18|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-10-21|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
==Projects and compilations== [[BikeTown Africa]] is a project that started in 2006 as a partnership between ''Bicycling'', [[Rodale Press]], [[Bristol Myers Squibb]], and [[Kona Bicycle Company]]. The project donates bicycles to healthcare workers in Africa, particularly those involved in [[HIV/AIDS]] related work.<ref>[http://www.healthcornertv.com/?ar=411HealthStory&m=06&y=2007 Bike Town Africa: Health Story], ''[[Health Corner]]'' show 411, April 29, 2007 & June 10, 2007</ref> ''Bicycling'' then documents the impact these bicycles have on the personal and professional lives of the recipients, such as in the May 2010 issue, where [[Dr. Travis]] (of the daytime television talk show ''[[The Doctors (2008 TV series)|The Doctors]]'') is interviewed about his involvement in BikeTown (among other things).<ref>[http://www.thedoctorstv.com/main/content/Bicycling_Dr_Travis Dr. Travis in ''Bicycling'' Magazine], thedoctorstv.com, retrieved April 2010</ref> In the same issue, ''Bicycling'' compiled a list of the 50 most bike-friendly cities in the United States, with [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] as number one.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/04/07/2010-04-07_mag_puts_city_in_top_10_for_biker_friendliness.html New York named eighth most bike-friendly city in America ''Bicycling'' magazine], Michael Pantelidis, ''[[New York Daily News]]'', 6 April 2010, retrieved 16 April 2010</ref>
==Publications== * [[David H Bryan]], [[T L Gettings]], ''Bicycling and photography'', 1979, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-282-3}} * [[David Lynn Smith]], [[Eugene A Gaston]], ''Get fit with bicycling'', 1979, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-283-0}} * ''Basic riding techniques'', 1979, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-284-7}} * [[Richard Jow]], ''Reconditioning the bicycle'', 1979, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-285-4}} * ''Basic bicycle repair'', 1980, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-315-8}} * [[Marcia Holoman]], [[John Schubert]], ''et al.'', ''The Most frequently asked questions about bicycling'', 1980, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-300-4}} * ''Best bicycle tours'', 1980, {{OCLC|381821071}} * ''Bicycling's best tours'', 1980, {{OCLC|7175346}} * [[Norman Sheil]], [[Pat Griffith]], ''Grand Prix training manual II'', 1982/1984, {{OCLC|41806979}} * ''The bicycling users' magazine'', 1982, {{OCLC|11347893}} * ''Bicycle Repair'', 1985<ref name=bccp>Bicycle Culture Center Publications List pp.11,17</ref> * ''Easy Bicycle Maintenance'', 1985<ref name=bccp /> * ''Complete Guide to Bicycle Maintenance and Repair'', 1986<ref name=bccp /> * [[Susan Weaver (author)|Susan Weaver]], ''Ride like a pro'', 1988, {{ISBN|978-0-87857-754-5}} * ''Cycling for Women'', 1989<ref name=bccp /> * ''New Bike Owner's Guide'', 1990<ref name=bccp /> * ''Long-Distance Cycling'', 1993<ref name=bccp />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.bicycling.com/}} * [http://www.rodaleinc.com/brand/bicycling ''Bicycling''] on Rodale's corporate website * [https://books.google.com/books/serial/ISSN:00062073 ''Bicycling''] at [[Google Books]] * [http://www.mtbr.com/cat/resources/magazine/bicycling/magazine/PRD_352387_132crx.aspx ''Bicycling'' magazine reviews], [[MTBR]].com (a [[mountain biking]] website, so reviews tend to be biased towards mountain bikes, despite ''Bicycling'' being geared towards on-road cycling—and [[Mountain Bike (magazine)|''Mountain Bike'']] targeted towards mountain biking)
{{Rodale}}

{{pp-vandalism|expiry=01:11, 3 January 2019|small=yes}} {{Infobox company | name = Big Baller Brand | logo = [[File:BigBallerBrand.jpg|UALogo Lockup blk|190px]] | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | traded_as = | founder = [[LaVar Ball]]{{cite news|last=Kay|first=Stanley|title=LaVar Ball now wants $3 billion for a Big Baller Brand co-branding deal|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2017/05/18/lavar-ball-big-baller-brand-worth-3-billion|magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=May 18, 2017|accessdate=May 20, 2017}} | key_people = [[LaVar Ball]]
{{small|(Founder, [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]])}}
Alan Foster
{{small|(Manager)}}{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Josh|title=The Big Baller Brand pop-up shop in Hong Kong was LIT|url=http://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2017/11/15/big-baller-brand-pop-up-shop-hong-kong-lavar-ball-lamelo-ball-liangelo-ball/|website=''Lonzo Ball Wire''|accessdate=February 12, 2018|date=November 15, 2017}} | products = [[Footwear]] and [[clothing|apparel]]
[[Bottled water]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = | parent = | footnotes = | homepage = {{URL|https://bigballerbrand.com}} | company_type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|2016}} | location = [[Chino Hills, California]], U.S. }} '''Big Baller Brand''' ('''BBB''') is an American company that designs, manufactures, and sells clothing and shoes. Launched in 2016 by media personality [[LaVar Ball]], it has most notably produced signature shoes for the Ball brothers: [[Lonzo Ball]] of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], and [[LaMelo Ball|LaMelo]] and [[LiAngelo Ball]] of the [[Los Angeles Ballers]]. Big Baller Brand has additionally been involved in the creation of the [[Junior Basketball Association]] (JBA), which it will fully fund, and both the [[Big Baller Brand Challenge Games]] and [[Big Baller Brand International Tournament]], which were a series of [[Lithuania|Lithuanian]] exhibition games hosted by [[BC_Prienai|BC Vytautas]] that featured LaMelo and LiAngelo Ball. == Origins and history == [[File:Chino-hills-skyline.jpg|thumb|Big Baller Brand was founded by [[LaVar Ball]] in [[Chino Hills, California]] (pictured).]] On April 14, 2016, Big Baller Brand announced that it would [[soft launch]] by June 2016.{{cite web|title=Launching!|url=https://bigballerbrand.com/blogs/news/97429057-launching#|website=''BigBallerBrand.com''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=April 14, 2016}} Founded by [[personal trainer]] and retired [[American football|football]] player [[LaVar Ball]], the company was built on "core family values," according to its website.{{cite web|last1=Lauletta|first1=Tyler|title=How the LaVar Ball family went from backyard training to potentially the next basketball family dynasty|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lavar-ball-family-lonzo-2017-6|website=''[[Business Insider]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=June 22, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Stephens|first1=Mitch|title=The Architect: Father of the Ball brothers speaks about growth of Chino Hills|url=http://www.maxpreps.com/news/jHzX-KpBGky5RKqc8SXiYA/the-architect--father-of-the-ball-brothers-speaks-about-growth-of-chino-hills.htm|website=''[[MaxPreps]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=March 26, 2016}}{{cite web|title=About Us|url=https://bigballerbrand.com/pages/about-us|website=''BigBallerBrand.com''|accessdate=February 11, 2018}}{{cite web|last1=Fenno|first1=Nathan|title=Big Baller Brand sued by apparel company over payments for hats, T-shirts|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-big-baller-lawsuit-20180108-story.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=January 8, 2018}} Ball later said that he created Big Baller Brand, which was based in [[Chino Hills, California]], for his three sons: [[Lonzo Ball|Lonzo]], [[LiAngelo Ball|LiAngelo]], and [[LaMelo Ball]], who all played basketball at [[Chino Hills High School]] when it was established.{{cite web|last1=Gregory|first1=Sean|title=How One Family Is Beating the NCAA at Its Own Game|url=http://time.com/4699494/lonzo-ball-lavar-ball-ucla-ncaa-tournament/|website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=March 15, 2017}} He also stated that each of the three Bs on the company's logo stands for one of his sons. Upon its launch in June, Big Baller Brand initially sold [[T-shirt]]s, [[shorts]], and sweatshirts through its online store.{{cite web|last1=DePaula|first1=Nick|last2=Rovell|first2=Darren|title=Big Baller Brand set to deliver to customers, fulfilling LaVar's vision|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/21519419/more-year-build-big-baller-brand-expected-ship-first-signature-shoe-today|website=''[[ESPN]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=November 24, 2017}} It partnered with a local design, printing, and shipping company, Garment Decor. In 2017, it also began working with sneaker company Brandblack for assistance in its shoe design.{{cite web|last1=Woolf|first1=Jake|title=How Big Baller Brand Was Saved by a Skechers-Funded Sneaker Start-Up|url=https://www.gq.com/story/big-baller-brand-lonzo-sneakers-brand-black-skechers|website=[[GQ]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=November 17, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=DePaula|first1=Nick|last2=Rovell|first2=Darren|title=Unboxing the Big Baller Brand ZO2 Prime Remix|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/21608445/unboxing-big-baller-brand-zo2-prime-remix|website=''[[ESPN]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=November 29, 2017}} To maintain independence from Big Baller Brand, however, Brandblack created an offshoot creative agency Santa Ana Design for the partnership. Alan Foster, a family friend of LaVar Ball, has additionally become a manager and business associate of Big Baller Brand, helping design its signature shoes.{{cite web|last1=Peter|first1=Josh|title=Building Basketball Brand on Ball Brothers|url=https://www.athleticbusiness.com/people/building-basketball-brand-on-ball-brothers.html|website=''AthleticBusiness.com''|accessdate=February 12, 2018|date=March 2017}} On March 7, 2017, Big Baller Brand was registered with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]], and its official slogan "Built for this" was trademarked on February 7, 2018 after being filed for in May 2017.{{cite web|title=Big Baller Brand: Trademark Details|url=https://trademarks.justia.com/870/45/big-baller-87045829.html|website=''USPTO''|accessdate=February 11, 2018}}{{cite web|title="Built for this": Trademark Details|url=https://trademarks.justia.com/870/45/built-for-87045827.html|website=''USPTO''|accessdate=February 11, 2018}} ==Products== ===Sportswear=== In May 2017, Big Baller Brand announced a November 2017 release of its first signature shoe, the ZO2 for [[Lonzo Ball]].{{cite news|last=Rovell|first=Darren|title=Ball debuts shoe line; main pair to cost $495|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/19311049/big-baller-brand-unveils-debut-zo2-shoe-lonzo-ball|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 6, 2017}} The base price of $495 garnered significant media attention.{{cite news|last=Tracy|first=Marc|title=At $495, Lonzo Ball’s ZO2 Sneakers Have Tastemakers Saying No Thanks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/05/sports/basketball/lonzo-lavar-ball-shoes-zo2.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 6, 2017}}{{cite news|title=Athletes react to Big Baller Brand's ZO2 release|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2017/05/05/big-baller-brand-lonzo-shoe-athletes-react|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 6, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Bieler|first=Des|title=Big Baller Brand’s $500 shoes are another shameless — and smart — move by LaVar Ball|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/05/05/big-baller-brands-500-shoes-are-another-shameless-and-smart-move-by-lavar-ball/|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 7, 2017}} LaVar Ball responded on [[Twitter]] to critiques of the shoes' price: "If you can't afford the ZO2'S, you're NOT a BIG BALLER," for which he received further media criticism.{{cite news|last=Wells|first=Adam|title=LaVar Ball Says Anyone Who Can't Afford Lonzo's ZO2 Isn't a 'Big Baller'|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2707881-lavar-ball-says-anyone-who-cant-afford-lonzos-zo2-isnt-a-big-baller|publisher=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 6, 2017}} In an interview with [[Colin Cowherd]] in May 2017, Ball said that if the big shoe companies like [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Adidas]], or [[Under Armour]] want to make a deal with his Big Baller Brand, the asking price is $3 billion. He also said that Baller has sold between 400 to 520 ZO2 shoes.{{cite news|title=LaVar Ball wants $3B for shoe deal, sees no need to market to women|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/19404697/lavar-ball-now-wants-3b-shoe-cos-want-get-deal|publisher=ESPN|date=May 18, 2017|accessdate=November 21, 2017}} In another interview, Ball described the shoes as "stitching and glue," stating that they were "not that big of a deal."{{cite news|last=Barnewall|first=Chris|title=LaVar Ball says $495 Big Baller Brand shoes nothing more than 'stitching and glue'|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/lavar-ball-says-495-big-baller-brand-shoes-nothing-more-than-stitching-and-glue/|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=June 5, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}} On August 31, 2017, it announced the release of a signature shoe for [[LaMelo Ball]], called the Melo Ball 1 (MB1), which was scheduled to be available in late 2017. According to Big Baller Brand, the shoe will be exceptionally light upon a request by Ball himself. The MB1 is currently priced at $395.{{cite news|last=Calle|first=Franklyn|title=LaMelo Ball Debuts The MB1 By Big Baller Brand|url=http://www.slamonline.com/kicks/lamelo-ball-signature-sneaker-mb1|magazine=[[Slam (magazine)|SLAM Magazine]]|date=August 31, 2017|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Gould|first=Andrew|title=Big Baller Brand Unveils MB1 Signature Sneakers for LaMelo Ball|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2730703-big-baller-brand-unveils-mb1-signature-sneakers-for-lamelo-ball|publisher=Bleacher Report|date=August 31, 2017|accessdate=September 8, 2017}} On December 4, 2017, Big Baller Brand revealed plans to create a signature shoe, known as the Gelo 3, for [[LiAngelo Ball]] after he left [[UCLA Bruins men's basketball|UCLA]], following a shoplifting incident in China.{{cite web|last1=Polacek|first1=Scott|title=LiAngelo Ball to Get Signature 'Gelo 3' Big Baller Brand Shoe After Leaving UCLA|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2747616-liangelo-ball-to-get-signature-gelo-3-big-baller-brand-shoe-after-leaving-ucla|website=''[[Bleacher Report]]''|accessdate=February 12, 2018|date=December 4, 2017}} Similar to the MB1, the Gelo 3 is also set at around $395. However, his shoes would later be renamed to the G3 Lux during his playing time in Lithuania. The company's founder, [[LaVar Ball]], also announced he would have signature shoes of not just his own, but a brand for his wife as well. LaVar's shoes are considered to be named "LaVariccis," while Tina Ball's signature shoes would be named "The Comeback," which was inspired by her recovery from a stroke she had in 2017.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/05/03/lavar-ball-reveals-name-of-tina-balls-future-big-baller-brand-shoe/ On October 17, 2018, Big Baller Brand released a cheaper version of Lonzo's shoe, the ZO2.19, priced at $200. {{cite web|url=https://bigballerbrand.com/collections/video|title=Footwear BSG Inc.|accessdate=October 17, 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/25008416/big-baller-brand-comes-cheaper-shoe|title=LaVar Ball's company comes out with cheaper shoe|first1=Darren|last1= Rovell|first2= Nick |last2=DePaula|work=ESPN|date=October 17, 2018|accessdate=October 17, 2018}} === Other products === After [[LiAngelo Ball|LiAngelo]] and [[LaMelo Ball]] signed their first professional contracts with [[BC Prienai|Vytautas Prienai–Birštonas]] of the [[Lithuanian Basketball League]] (LKL), Big Baller Brand saw an increased presence in Lithuania in 2018.{{cite web|last1=Amick|first1=Sam|title=LaMelo, LiAngelo Ball sign with Lithuanian pro team|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2017/12/11/lamelo-liangelo-ball-sign-lithuanian-pro-team/942657001/|website=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=December 11, 2018}} On February 9, 2018, Big Baller Brand announced its partnership with the Lithuanian [[bottled water]] company [[Birštonas]] Mineral Water, a sponsor of Vytautas.{{cite web|last1=Moton|first1=Maurice|title=LaVar Ball, Big Baller Brand Announce Partnership with Lithuanian Water Company|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2758679-lavar-ball-big-baller-brand-announce-partnership-with-lithuanian-water-company|website=''[[Bleacher Report]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=February 9, 2018}} LaVar Ball stated that Big Baller Brand would import water from Lithuania to the United States with a price similar to [[Perrier]] and [[S.Pellegrino]] products.{{cite web|last1=Tsuji|first1=Alysha|title=LaVar Ball says he's going to sell Big Baller Brand water|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2018/02/lavar-ball-big-baller-brand-lithuania-mineral-water-plans|website=''For The Win''|accessdate=February 12, 2018|date=February 9, 2018}} == Sponsorship == On December 20, 2017, [[LaVar Ball]] announced the creation of the [[Junior Basketball Association]] (JBA), a professional league completely funded by Big Baller Brand that is designed as an alternative to [[college basketball]] for high school graduates.{{cite web|last1=Rovell|first1=Darren|title=LaVar Ball plans to start league for high school graduates|url=http://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/21827823/lavar-ball-wants-start-league-high-school-graduates|website=''[[ESPN]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=December 21, 2017}} The league, which is set to launch in the summer of 2018, is expected to pay players $3,000 to $10,000 per month and include teams from several major American cities.{{cite web|last1=Destefano|first1=Mike|title=LaVar Ball Just Took a Big Step Toward Forming His Own Basketball League|url=http://www.complex.com/sports/2018/01/lavar-ball-big-step-forming-own-basketball-league|website=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=January 18, 2018}} According to Ball, players will be required to exclusively wear Big Baller Brand products, with uniforms, shoes, and other apparel provided by the company.{{cite web|last1=Rapaport|first1=Daniel|title=LaVar Ball Wants to Start a League for Players Who Don't Want to Go to College|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2017/12/20/lavar-ball-big-baller-brand-junior-basketball-association-league|website=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=December 20, 2017}} On May 4, 2018, LaVar's youngest son, [[LaMelo Ball]], was confirmed to be one of the players entering the upstart league, while also being touted as the face of the league by his father.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/05/04/lamelo-ball-los-angeles-ballers-jba-league-lavar-ball-big-baller-brand/ On January 5, 2018, Vytautas, the first professional team of LaMelo and LiAngelo Ball, announced that it would withdraw from the [[Baltic Basketball League]] (BBL) and in its place host five exhibition games to showcase the Ball brothers, called the [[Big Baller Brand Challenge Games]].{{cite web|last1=Rapaport|first1=Daniel|title=Prienu Vytautas to Play in 'Big Baller Brand Challenge Games'|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2018/01/05/prienu-vytautas-big-baller-brand-challenge-games-lithuania|website=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=January 5, 2018}} The games, which took place from January 9 to January 29 and were live streamed through [[Facebook]], featured widespread advertisement of Big Baller Brand, with [[Business Insider]] commenting that the company was "the real star of the show."{{cite web|last1=Lauletta|first1=Tyler|title=Over 100,000 people watched LaMelo and LiAngelo Ball's Lithuanian debut on Facebook — and they were treated to a huge ad for Big Baller Brand|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lamelo-ball-facebook-lithuania-debut-big-baller-brand-2018-1|website=''[[Business Insider]]''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=January 9, 2018}} Shortly after the Ball brothers began playing professionally, LaVar Ball heavily invested in Vytautas, helping it pay off its debts and allowing Big Baller Brand to become the team's main sponsor as a result.{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Josh|title=LaVar Ball paid 'a lot of money' for Big Baller Brand to sponsor LiAngelo, LaMelo's team|url=http://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/02/02/lavar-ball-big-baller-brand-liangelo-lamelo-vytautas/|website=''Lonzo Ball Wire''|accessdate=February 11, 2018|date=February 2, 2018}} The team would also be involved with the [[Big Baller Brand International Tournament]] and a few other exhibition games involving the [[Chinese Basketball Association]]'s [[Guangdong Southern Tigers]] and the [[British Basketball League]]'s [[London Lions (basketball)|London Lions]] during the 2017–18 season, with the Big Baller Brand's founder coaching the team during those events. On February 15, 2018, Lonzo Ball would release his debut rap album, [[Born 2 Ball]], under the Big Baller Music Group. The label would be a subsidiary of the Big Baller Brand and would be run by a close friend of LaVar's. In April 2018, after previously wearing the ZO2 shoes during a game, [[Jordan Crawford]] would be the first professional basketball player not related to the Ball family to look into having a partnership with the company.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/04/15/big-baller-brand-jordan-crawford-pelicans-nba-playoffs-zo2-prime-remix/ Crawford also gave the company words of approval for what they're doing.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/04/16/jordan-crawford-lavar-ball-lonzo-ball-big-baller-brand-pelicans-nba-playoffs/ A month later, rapper [[Quavo]] of [[Migos]] fame would be seen promoting Lonzo Ball's Big Baller Brand merchandise on [[Instagram]], with later reports suggesting that Quavo would be an ambassador of the Big Baller Brand.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/05/18/quavo-migos-big-baller-brand-instagram-lonzo-ball/https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/05/19/big-baller-brand-migos-quavo-ambassador/ ==Customer service== In January 2018, Big Baller Brand was given an F grade by the [[Better Business Bureau]], which said that Big Baller Brand "has a pattern of complaints", specifically that many customers have had to wait "weeks or even months to receive their order". Some customers alleged that they have received the wrong merchandise or even nothing at all, and that it had been difficult to contact the company.{{cite web|last1=Bieler|first1=Des|title=LaVar Ball’s Big Baller Brand gets ‘F’ rating from Better Business Bureau|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2018/01/08/lavar-balls-big-baller-brand-gets-f-rating-from-better-business-bureau/|publisher=''The Washington Post''|accessdate=9 January 2018|date=8 January 2018}} In May 2018, [[MLB All-Star|All-Star baseball]] player [[Adam Jones (baseball)|Adam Jones]] complained on social media that he just received his ZO2 Prime Remix shoes after ordering them a year earlier.https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/05/08/mlb-all-star-adam-jones-big-baller-brand-zo2-prime-remix-lonzo-ball-orioles/ ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://bigballerbrand.com/ Official website] {{Lonzo Ball}} [[Category:2016 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:American companies established in 2016]]

{{about||the retail complex in Birmingham, UK|Bull Ring, Birmingham|other uses|Bull Ring (disambiguation)}} [[File:Spain Andalusia Malaga BW 2015-10-24 09-52-48.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Málaga]]'s bullring lies in the heart of the city]] [[File:Plaza de Toros de la Maestranza.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Façade of the oldest bullring in Spain, [[La Maestranza]], in [[Seville]]]] [[File:PlazadetorosMexico.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The [[Plaza México]] situated in Mexico City, is the world's largest bullring]] [[File:Nimes amphi.jpg|thumb|250px|Exterior facade of the [[Arena of Nîmes|arena]] in [[Nîmes]], a converted Roman amphitheatre]] [[File:Plaza de Toros, Bullfighting ring in Ronda, Spain 2.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Plaza de Toros de Ronda]]]] [[File:MADRID 060725 MXALX 106 (5786603433).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Plaza de Toros de [[Chinchón]]]]
A '''bullring''' is an [[arena]] where [[bullfighting]] is performed. Bullrings are often associated with Spain, but they can also be found in neighboring countries and the [[New World]]. Bullrings are often historic and culturally significant centres that bear many structural similarities to the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] [[amphitheatre]].
== Common structure == The classic bullring is an enclosed, roughly circular amphitheatre with tiered rows of stands that surround an open central space. The open space forms the arena or ''ruedo'', a field of densely packed crushed rock (''[[albero]]'') that is the stage for the bullfight. Also on the ground level, the central arena is surrounded by a staging area where the bullfighters prepare and take refuge, called the ''callejón'' (alley). The ''callejón'' is separated from the arena by a wall or other structure, usually made of wood and roughly 140 cm high. The partition wall has doors for the entrance and exit of the bull (''puerta de los toriles'') and human participants (''puerta de cuadrilla''), although the form, number, and placement of these doors will vary from one bullring to another. In regular places, the wall is pushed outwards leaving splits (''burladero'', from burlar: to evade, to dodge) that allow the bullfighters to go in the arena and to take refuge but are too narrow for the bull. Nevertheless, on rare occasions the bull jumps the wall causing havoc in the corridor. The walls also have a type of stirrup or foothold that aids in crossing over to the central arena, and sometimes stirrups on the arena side as well; these are used mostly by event staff if they need to intervene quickly in the case of an emergency. The arena is surrounded by climbing rows of seats. The seats are priced differently according to the position of the sun during the show, normally in the afternoon. The hot ''sol'', "sun", is cheaper than the fresher ''sombra'', "shade".
== Architectural origins == {{unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} Bullrings evolved as specialized sporting arenas hand-in-hand with the sport that demanded them. Many of the ancient Roman amphitheatres had characteristics that can be seen in the bullrings of today (in fact the ring in [[Nîmes]], France, is a Roman artifact, though it is more elliptical than the usual plaza), and the origin of [[bullfighting]] is very closely related to certain Roman traditions; in the formative years of the sport on the [[Iberian Peninsula]], those Roman enclosures were not commonly utilised for bullfighting events. Back when bullfighting festivals were conducted principally on horseback, the spectacle was a more public affair that took place in the city's open [[plaza]] area. It was only later, when bullfights were conducted principally by men on foot, that the public needed a structure to house them appropriately. Not only did the crowd need special seating to view the spectacle, they also needed a structure to contain the general disorder that reigned at festivals during the heyday of such legendary figures as [[Costillares]], [[Pedro Romero]], and [[Pepe-Hillo]].
In these early days, the circular form was not to be taken for granted. When [[Maestranza (Seville)|La Maestranza]] bullring in [[Seville]] was authorized for construction in 1730 specifically to house bullfights, the original plans called for a rectangular arena for the first three years, only later to be changed to a circular form that avoided the cornering of the action and put all viewers at the same approximate distance, the same reason for the elliptical form of amphitheatres. Another circular plaza was begun in [[Ronda]] in 1754, and it featured its first bullfights in 1782.
In the change from the 19th to the 20th century, the [[Neo-Mudéjar]] style became in vogue for plazas, involving decoration in visible brickwork.
Since the 1990s, new construction technology allows some rings to be covered permanently or temporarily.
==Alternative uses== The primary purpose of the ring is bullfighting, but it is usually limited to some festival weeks in the year. In other times, it may be used as a concert venue as in the ''[[Rock en el ruedo]]'' tour of [[Miguel Ríos]] or the live record ''[[Diamonds & Rust in the Bullring]]'', featuring a [[Joan Baez]] concert in the Bilbao plaza.
Before the diffusion of modern sports premises, bullrings were used in the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]] for [[Basque Country (greater region)#Traditional Basque sports|traditional sports]] similar to challenges of [[Strength training|resistance running]]. The public made bets on the number of laps the runner could make. No bulls were involved.
After the [[battle of Badajoz (1936)]] of the [[Spanish Civil War]], the Badajoz ring was used as a confinement camp for supporters of [[Second Spanish Republic|the republic]] and many thousands were executed there by the Nationalist forces who had just occupied the town.
Most indoor bullrings, especially in Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America, in addition to being used for concerts, have also been used for indoor sports such as [[basketball]], [[ice hockey]], [[boxing]] and [[lucha libre]].
== Bullrings of the world == The most famous bullrings in the world are [[Las Ventas|Plaza de Toros de Las Ventas]] in [[Madrid]] (Spain), widely regarded as the most prestigious one, [[La Maestranza]] in [[Seville]] (Spain), and [[Plaza de Toros México]] in Mexico.{{cn|date=January 2016}}
===Europe=== ====France==== *The [[Arena of Nîmes]], [[Nîmes]] *The arena in [[Arles]] *The arena in [[Alès]] *The arena in Mont de Marsan *The arena in Bouillargues *The arena in [[Vauvert]] *There are also arenas in an important part of small villages of [[Camargue]] Villages round the Camargue, such as Rodilhan in the Gard, who also practise 'mise à mort' - killing the bull.

Martin Centre''' is an athletics center in the [[Northwestern United States|northwest]] [[United States]], on the campus of [[Gonzaga University]] in [[Spokane, Washington]]. Its multi-purpose [[arena]] has a [[seating capacity]] of 4,000.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZWdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5fIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5939%2C7093609 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=(Spokane, Washington)|title=Our region's arenas |date=November 18, 2004 |page=O8 }} Ground was broken in June 1964 on the [[United States dollar|$]]1.1 million center, which opened in late 1965 as the '''[[John F. Kennedy]] Memorial Pavilion''', with a capacity of 3,800 for basketball.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FzlWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AOkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7058%2C2093278 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington)|last=Missildine |first=Harry |title=Kennedy Pavilion heralds modern Gonzaga sports era |date=May 21, 1965 |page=28 }}[http://www.ledzeppelin-database.com/geekbaseweb/forumpage.aspx?g=posts&t=30 Venue information and background] The center included a 6-lane {{convert|25|yd|0|sing=on}} swimming pool. The dedication ceremony on November 21 was attended by 6,000 and included the late [[President of the United States|president's]] brother, [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Kennedy]] of [[Massachusetts]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mbszAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qfcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6393%2C5751766 |work=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington) |title=GU names 3 to take part in dedication |date=November 20, 1965 |page=3}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_LNWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_-gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5274%2C2192836 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington) |title=JFK edifice is dedicated |date=November 22, 1965 |page=1}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sb1eAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CTEMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4201%2C4299408 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |agency=Associated Press |title=Assassination forced clearer thinking, says Edward Kennedy |date=November 22, 1965 |page=1}} The first varsity event on December 3 was a basketball game against [[Washington State Cougars men's basketball|Washington State]], won by the visiting Cougars {{nowrap|106–78}} before an overflow crowd of 4,300.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wrRWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0ugDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6886%2C904912 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington)|last=Missildine |first=Harry |title=New Pavilion big success - for Cougars |date=December 4, 1965 |page=8}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kbdeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bTAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2979%2C813714 |newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune |location=(Idaho) |last=Keidan |first=Bruce |title=Cougars break point mark in drubbing 'Zags |date=December 4, 1965 |page=8}} Charlotte Martin, the daughter-in-law of former governor [[Clarence D. Martin]],{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YbsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=1716%2C3001931 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |title=Advocate of education Charlotte Martin dies |last=Wagoner |first=Richard |date=November 4, 1987 |page=A1 }} donated $4.5 million in 1987 for the renovation of the complex and it was renamed for her as part of Gonzaga's centennial celebrations on {{nowrap|March 17.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UBATAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DvsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2141%2C437977 |newspaper=Spokane Chronicle|location=(Washington)|last=Sparks |first=Jim |title=Gonzaga dedicates center - with a flair |date=March 18, 1987 |page=A3 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.cstv.com/auto_pdf/p_hotos/s_chools/gonz/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/0607mediaguidep99-112 |title=Through The Ages – Homes of the Bulldogs |work=2007 Gonzaga University Men's Basketball Media Guide |publisher=Gonzaga University Athletics |format=PDF |page=108 |accessdate=2007-05-29}}}} Mrs. Martin died less than eight months later, at age 68. The Martin Centre is the home court of the women's [[volleyball]] team, and was home of [[Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball|men's]] and women's [[basketball]] teams until the fall of [[2004–05 Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball team|2004]], when the adjacent $25 million [[McCarthey Athletic Center]] (MAC) opened.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZWdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5fIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2813%2C7077779 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=(Spokane, Washington) |title=Welcome home |last=Bergum |first=Steve |date=November 18, 2004 |page=O2 }} An exception was the partial hiatus in the {{nowrap|1979–80}} season when the men's team returned to its former home of the [[Spokane Coliseum]] for [[West Coast Conference|WCAC]] home games only,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ogokAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IQgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1783%2C7568082 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review|location=(Spokane, Washington)|title=Zags are paying - for visiting teams, vacant Kennedy Pavilion |last=Missildine |first=Harry |date=February 15, 1980 |page=25 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.cstv.com/auto_pdf/p_hotos/s_chools/gonz/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/0607mediaguidep123-133 |title=Year-by-Year Results |work=2007 Gonzaga University Men's Basketball Media Guide |publisher=Gonzaga University Athletics |format=PDF |pages=123–133 |accessdate=2007-06-03}} The Pavilion was affectionately known as ''The Kennel'', a reference to the enthusiastic capacity crowds for Bulldog basketball, a nickname which transferred to the MAC. Prior to the Spokane Coliseum's opening in 1955, Gonzaga basketball games were played on campus at "The Cave," a gymnasium in the administration building. In late [[1968 in music|1968]], the English rock group [[Led Zeppelin]] played their fifth-ever American concert at the Kennedy Pavilion on December 30, opening for [[Vanilla Fudge]] and erroneously billed as "Len Zefflin";{{cite web |url=http://www.ledzeppelin.com/show/december-30-1968 |work=Led Zeppelin |title=Shows: 1968, Spokane, Washington |date=December 30, 1968 |accessdate=November 18, 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZGtYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FPgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2045%2C3695320|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington)|agency=(advertisement)|title=Concerts West presents:|date=December 30, 1968 |page=18}} the first known [[bootleg recording]] of the band originated from this performance.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aO60PT4GniQ |title=Gonzaga '68 |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=2008-05-15}} The bands were welcomed to Spokane with frigid sub-zero temperatures.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZWtYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FPgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7266%2C3971592 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=(Washington)|title=Cold easing: mercury hits zero|date=December 31, 1968 |page=1}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == *{{official|http://www.gozags.com/facilities/gonz-martin-centre.html}} {{Gonzaga Bulldogs men's basketball navbox}}{{Gonzaga University}} [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Gonzaga Bulldogs basketball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Spokane, Washington]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1965]] {{Washington-stadium-stub}}

{{Infobox surf club | title = Coogee | image = | fullname = Coogee Surf Life Saving Club | founded = 1907 | members = 500 senior, 250 [[Nippers|junior]] | club_colors = | website = | pattern = | pattern_size = }} The '''Coogee Surf Life Saving Club''' is a foundation member of the [[surf lifesaving]] movement in [[Australia]]. It was founded in 1907 by a group of concerned locals and has a proud history of no lives being lost whilst its members have patrolled. Coogee SLSC celebrated its 100-year anniversary in 2007, the Year of the Lifesaver.
Coogee SLSC has a history, which includes many firsts in the lifesaving movement. These include the first night surf carnival, the first mass rescue, the first [[shark attack]] and the development of the [[resuscitation]] technique. The Coogee SLSC clubhouse sits at the southern end of [[Coogee beach]]. The club's activities are managed and run by volunteers, with the assistance of a variety of community concerned sponsors, including Sydney City Renault.
Coogee SLSC has a representative on the [[Wylie's Baths]] Trust and conducts patrols at [[Wylie's Baths]] during summer.
The Club conducts an annual swimming event around [[Wedding Cake Island]] each November. The event began in 2000 and attracts hundreds of competitors each year and is a prominent event on the Sydney Ocean Swim calendar.

{{Other uses}} {{Globalize|date=December 2010}} [[Image:Decoys.jpg|thumb|Carved, wooden [[duck decoy (model)|duck decoy]]s]]
A '''decoy''' (derived from the ''duck-coy'', "[[Duck decoy (structure)|duck cage]]"<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wedgwood|first=Hensleigh|authorlink=Hensleigh Wedgwood|title=On False Etymologies|journal=Transactions of the Philological Society|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3924121;view=1up;seq=81|year=1855|issue=6|pages=71}}</ref>) is usually a person, [[tool|device]], or event meant as a distraction, to hide what an individual or a group might be looking for. Decoys have been used for centuries most notably in game [[hunting]], but also in [[war]]time and in the committing or resolving of [[crime]]s.
[[Image:Decoy_in_action.png|thumb|Illustration demonstrating the use of a dog in a duck decoy tunnel (1886)]]
The term decoy may refer to two distinct devices, both used for hunting wildfowl. One is a long cone-shaped [[wickerwork]] tunnel installed on a small pond to catch wild [[duck]]s. After the ducks settled on the pond, a small, trained dog would herd the birds into the tunnel. The catch was formerly sent to market for food, but now these are used only to catch ducks to be [[Bird ringing|ring]]ed and released: see [[ornithology]]. The word ''decoy'', also originally found in English as "coy", derives from the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] ''de Kooi'' (the cage) and dates back to the early 17th century, when this type of duck trap was introduced to England from the Netherlands. As "decoy" came more commonly to signify a person or a device than a pond with a cage-trap, the latter acquired the [[retronym]] "decoy pool".{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
The other form of duck decoy, otherwise known as a ''hunting decoy'' or ''wildfowl decoy'', is a life-size model of the creature. The hunter places a number about the hunting area as they will encourage wild birds to land nearby, hopefully within the range of the concealed hunter. Originally carved from wood, they are now made from plastic.
Wildfowl decoys (primarily ducks, geese, shorebirds, and crows, but including some other species) are considered a form of [[folk art]]. Collecting decoys has become a significant hobby both for folk art collectors and hunters. The world record was set in September 2007 when a pintail drake and Canada goose, both by [[A. Elmer Crowell]] sold for 1.13 million apiece.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ducks and Decoys|last=Frangoulis|first=George|publisher=The Farmstead Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-312-60897-9|location=tuscaloosa, Alabama}}</ref>
==Military decoy== [[Image:DummyShermanTank.jpg|thumb|An inflatable [[dummy tank]], modeled after the World War 2, [[M4 Sherman]]]] {{Main|Military dummy}} The decoy in war is a low-cost device intended to represent a real item of military equipment. They may be deployed in amongst their real counterparts, to fool enemy forces into attacking them and so protect the real items of equipment by diverting fire away from them.
Alternatively, large numbers of military decoys, or dummys, may be deployed as an aspect of [[Military deception]]. Their purpose is to fool the enemy into believing forces in a particular area are much stronger than they really are. One notable example are [[Quaker Gun]]s.
For a [[defense (military)|defense]] system, decoys and [[Chaff (radar countermeasure)|chaff]] for [[ICBM]]s would mainly work in mid-course: during the boost phase they would be inside the [[rocket]], because separate rockets for each of many decoys would not be practical, while at [[atmospheric reentry]] light decoys and chaff considerably slow down and/or are destroyed in the [[Earth's atmosphere|atmosphere]].
===Bomb decoy=== In [[irregular warfare]], [[improvised explosive device]]s are commonly used as roadside bombs to target military patrols. Some [[Guerrilla warfare|guerillas]] also use imitation IEDs to intimidate civilians,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/four-decoy-ieds-found-port-said-polling-stations|title=Four decoy IEDs found in Port Said polling stations - Egypt Independent|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://wardiaries.wikileaks.org/id/10228/|title=DECOY IED FOUND BY 1BCT WEST OF SAMARRA|publisher=}}</ref> to waste [[bomb disposal]] resources,<ref>http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a528332.pdf</ref> or to set up an ambush.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/28/health/research/28brain.html|title=In Battle, Hunches Prove to Be Valuable|date=28 July 2009|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>[http://www.usmcofficer.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Improvised-Explosive-Devices.pdf "One enemy TTP is to set decoy IEDs in order to observe the immediate reactions of coalition forces. By studying our tactics they can increase the lethality of their attacks, like setting up mortars and rockets on the kill zone or safe area." (PDF)]</ref><ref name="Lebovic2010">{{cite book|author=James H. Lebovic|title=The Limits of U.S. Military Capability: Lessons from Vietnam and Iraq|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-dbYsfiKV8UC|date=1 August 2010|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-9750-4|page=62}}</ref> Some terrorist groups use fake bombs during a [[hostage]] siege, in order to limit hostage rescue efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newsvideo/8743685/Man-takes-female-hostage-in-Sydney-office-bomb-siege.html|title=Video: Man takes female hostage in Sydney office bomb siege - Telegraph|author=Bonnie Malkin in Sydney|date=6 September 2011|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref><ref>http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/police-defend-waiting-11-hours-to-storm-parramatta-building-after-man-with-12-year-old-girl-said-he-had-bom/story-e6freuzi-1226130987671</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/how-sydney-siege-gunman-tricked-police-into-thinking-there-was-a-bomb-in-his-backpack-20141217-129fqi.html|title=How Sydney siege gunman tricked police into thinking there was a bomb in his backpack|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
=== Sonar decoy === {{Main article|Sonar decoy}}
==In biochemistry== In biochemistry, there are decoy [[receptor (biochemistry)|receptors]], decoy [[Substrate (biochemistry)|substrates]] and decoy [[ribonucleic acid|RNA]]. In addition, digital decoys are used in [[protein folding]] simulations.
===Decoy receptor=== <!--Decoy receptor redirects here--> [[Decoy receptors]], or sink receptors,<ref name=vegf>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=eurekah.section.2469|title=Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor|author=Hugo H. Marti|publisher=}}</ref> are receptors that bind a [[ligand]], inhibiting it from binding to its normal receptor. For instance, the receptor [[VEGFR-1]] can prevent [[vascular endothelial growth factor]] (VEGF) from binding to the [[VEGFR-2]]<ref name=vegf/> The [[TNF inhibitor]] [[etanercept]] exerts its anti-inflammatory effect by being a decoy receptor that binds to TNF.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Zalevsky J, Secher T, Ezhevsky SA |title=Dominant-negative inhibitors of soluble TNF attenuate experimental arthritis without suppressing innate immunity to infection |journal=J. Immunol. |volume=179 |issue=3 |pages=1872–83 |date=August 2007 |pmid=17641054 |doi= 10.4049/jimmunol.179.3.1872|url=|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Decoy substrate=== <!--Psejjvnudosubstrate redirects here--> A ''decoy substrate'' or ''pseudosubstrate'' is a protein that has similar structure to the [[Substrate (biochemistry)|substrate]] of an [[enzyme]], in order to make the enzyme bind to the pseudosubstrate rather than to the real substrate, thus blocking the activity of the enzyme. These proteins are therefore [[enzyme inhibitor]]s.
Examples include [[K3L]] produced by [[vaccinia virus]], which prevents the [[immune system]] from phosphorylating the substrate [[eIF-2]] by having a similar structure to eIF-2. Thus, the vaccinia virus avoids the immune system.
===Digital decoys=== In protein folding simulations, a decoy is a computer-generated protein structure which is designed so to ''compete'' with the real structure of the protein. Decoys are used to test the validity of a protein model; the model is considered correct only if is able to identify the native state configuration of the protein among the decoys.
Decoys are generally used to overcome a main problem in protein folding simulations: the size of the [[Polymer chemistry|conformational space]]. For very detailed protein models, it can be practically impossible to explore all the possible configurations to find the native state. To deal with this problem, one can make use of decoys. The idea behind this is that it is unnecessary to search blindly through all possible conformations for the native conformation; the search can be limited to a relevant sub-set of structures. To start with, all non-compact configurations can be excluded. A typical decoy set will include globular conformations of various shapes, some having no secondary structures, some having helices and sheets in different proportions. The computer model being tested will be used to calculate the [[Thermodynamic free energy|free energy]] of the protein in the decoy configurations. The minimum requirement for the model to be correct is that it identifies the native state as the minimum free energy state (see [[Anfinsen's dogma]]).
==Decoys as folk art== {{Main|Waterfowl decoy collecting}} Ever since [[Joel Barber]], the first known decoy collector, started in 1918, decoys have become increasingly viewed as an important form of North American folk art. Barber's book [[Wild Fowl Decoys]], was the first book on decoys as collectible objects. It was followed in 1965 by folk art dealer Adele Earnest's "The Art of the Decoy" and "American Bird Decoys" by collector Wm. J. Mackey.
William J. Mackey made many trips to Chincoteague Island for the great flounder fishing as well as hunting for Chincoteague decoys. On his trips to the island he called Snug Harbor Marina home. He would send out locals to search for great finds of Chincoteague history. Cigar Daisey was one of the local Chincoteaguers that would help Mackey find all the best decoys that made his collection world-famous. Cigar has told many stories of the many truck loads of decoys he rounded up for his good friend. By that time a milestone in collecting had already occurred with the publication of "Decoy Collectors Guide", a small magazine created by hobbyists Hal & Barbara Sorenson of Burlington, Iowa. The 'Guide' helped foster a sense of community and provided a forum for collectors to share their research.
By the 1970s decoys were becoming big business, at least by previous standards. The death of Wm. F. Mackey brought his decoys to market in a series of auctions in 1973 and 1974, with the star of his collection, a Long-billed Curlew by Wm. 'Bill' Bowman selling for a record US$10,500.
Since the 1960s numerous collectors organizations have been created, specialist books and magazines published, with specialist dealers, and special interest shows around the US and Canada.
The largest collectors organization is the Midwest Decoy Collectors Association (MDCA)which despite its name is the de facto international group. MDCA is a non-profit, [501(c)(3)] organization which sponsors the biggest show of the year. There are numerous state and regional groups as well.
The current world record was set when two decoys (Canada goose and a preening pintail drake) by A. Elmer Crowell of East Harwich, MA were sold for $1.13 million each on September 19, 2007 by Stephen O'Brien Jr. Fine Arts, in what O'Brien describes as "the largest private sale of decoys ever." The decoys were part of a private sale of 31 decoys for $7.5 million. <ref>{{citenews|url=http://www.decoymag.com|title=Joe Engers, Editor of Decoy Magazine|accessdate=2018-08-30 | work=Decoy Magazine}}</ref>Joe Engers, Editor of Decoy Magazine, noted that O'Brien is one of the top dealers of decoys in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2007/09/21/to_tune_of_113m_decoys_are_the_real_thing/|title=To tune of $1.13m, decoys are the real thing|accessdate=2007-09-21 | work=The Boston Globe | date=2007-09-21}}</ref>
Among other admired makers were the Ward brothers, Lemuel (1896–1984) and Steven, of [[Crisfield]], [[Maryland]]. Their career output is estimated at between 27,000 and 40,000 birds, working and decorative.
One of the most famous decoy makers in recent times is [[Delbert Daisey|Delbert "Cigar" Daisey]] from Chincoteague Va. Cigar decoys are in high demand all over the country. The best decoy he ever made was a pintail that he made for his wife in 1973. This decoy was featured in National Geographic in June 1980 on page 826. This decoy is estimated to be worth between $100,000 - $150,000.
[[Fish decoy]] collecting is also quite popular. Especially ice fishing decoys. See also [[fishing lures]].

'''Economy rate''' (also known as the '''Jade Dernbach-o-meter''') is the average number of runs conceded per over in [[cricket]]. The calculation is (Econ = Runs/Overs bowled). Overs are written as decimals from 0.1 to 0.6, so must be converted into actual decimals (e.g. 0.3 Overs is actually 0.5 as 3 is half of 6) before used in the calculation.
==Overview== The economy rate is the average number of runs conceded for each over bowled. From the Bowler’s perspective, extras (byes and leg byes) are not counted as runs, hence not added to his tally of runs conceded in an over, but the error balls i.e. a [[Wide (cricket)|wide]] and [[no-ball]] are counted and added to his over, which is displayed in his bowling figure.<ref name="allthatcricket">{{cite web|url=http://allthatcricket.com/?p=1732 |title=Runs per Over (Economy Rate) | All That Cricket|publisher=allthatcricket.com|accessdate=2016-01-09}}</ref>
The economy rate is more important in one-day cricket and Twenty20 matches than in Test match cricket. The shorter forms of the game (ODI and T20) demand that bowlers (and fielders) restrict the flow of runs from the opposition to give their team a better chance of finishing the game with more runs on the board. In Tests, however, the priority when in the field is to bowl the opposition out and take all ten wickets in both the innings. A bowler's economy rate is normally calculated from their career record, but one might also calculate it for a specific period of time, such as a calendar year or the duration of a World Cup tournament. In one day matches, a career economy rate of less than five runs per over is good. Conceding too many quick runs in a Test match is sure to get you taken off by your captain and replaced with another bowler, while taking a wicket in limited overs matches invariably slows the run rate. Like many aspects of cricket, economy rate vs bowling average vs bowling strike rate is a matter of finding a good balance. In Twenty20 matches, anything under seven runs per over is considered to be good.<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://cricket.about.com/od/glossary/fl/Economy-rate.htm |title=Economy rate - Cricket Glossary|publisher=cricket.about.com|accessdate=2016-01-09}}</ref>
[[Jade Dernbach]] is at the top of the list of players who have the worst economy rates in [[One Day International cricket]] with 6.35 as economy rate.<ref name="sportskeeda">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/stat-worst-career-economy-rate-odis |title=Stats: Worst career economy rate in ODIs|publisher=sportskeeda.com|accessdate=2016-01-09}}</ref>

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Ghazir Club Court | nickname =The Green Fortress | image = Ghazir Club Court.png | fullname = | location = Ghazir, [[Lebanon]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ghazir Municipality | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Ghazir Volleyball]]
[[Hekmeh|Sagesse (Hekmeh BC)]] | seating_capacity = 4,500-5000 | }} '''Ghazir Club Court''' is an [[indoor arena]] located in Ghazir (few miles north of Beirut), [[Lebanon]]. The capacity of the arena is 4,500 spectators. It hosts indoor sporting events such as [[basketball]], [[volleyball]] and hosts the home matches of [[Hekmeh|Club Sagesse Beirut ]] since more than ten years until nowadays, the stadium bears the colors of Sagesse and also hosts Ghazir club [[basketball]] games and many other [[volleyball]] matches. It also hosted the [[1999 ABC Champions Cup|1999]] and [[2000 ABC/FIBA Asia Champions Cup]], the [[Lebanese Basketball League]] and cup and also the Lebanese Volleyball League. The venue also hosted the [[2010 FIBA Asia Stanković Cup]]. ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/middle_east/countries/lebanon.shtml Stadium information] {{coord|34|00|58.2|N|35|39|27.4|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Lebanon]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Lebanon]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Lebanon]] {{Lebanon-sports-venue-stub}}

[[Alexander Artemev]] |bronzeNOC = USA |prev = [[Gymnastics at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's artistic team all-around|2004]] |next = [[Gymnastics at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's artistic team all-around|2012]]}} {{GymnasticsAt2008SummerOlympics}} '''Men's artistic team all-around''' competition at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] was held at the [[Beijing National Indoor Stadium]] on August 12, 2008. Teams qualified through the general artistic qualification performances. Each team was composed of six gymnasts. Five of those gymnasts performed on each of the six apparatus, and four of those scores counted towards the team total. The eight teams with the best combined scores in the qualification moved on to the team final. In the team final, each team selected three gymnasts to compete on each apparatus. All three scores counted for the team score; the three scores on each apparatus were summed to give a final team score. ==Qualified teams== {{main|Gymnastics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's artistic qualification}} The eight teams with the highest scoresScoring in artistic gymnastics is based on two separate scores that are then combined in order to come to the final score. The A score measures the difficulty of each element (and combinations of elements) within the routine, while the B score evaluates the performance, ie, the "execution, composition and artistry" of the routine. For further information, please see the [[Code of Points (artistic gymnastics)|Code of Points]] article. in [[Gymnastics at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's artistic qualification|qualifying]] proceed to the men's artistic team finals. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" !
