revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Georgios Karaiskakis Stadium | nickname = "Karaiskakis Stadium" | image = [[File:Karaiskakis Stadium Piraeus Olympiacos-Arsenal.jpg|310px|none|Karaiskakis Stadium Piraeus before Olympiacos-Arsenal FC]] '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA Category 3 Stadium]]'''
[[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|15px]][[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|15px]][[Image:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|15px]][https://www.worldstadiumdatabase.com/list-of-uefa-category-3-stadiums.htm List of UEFA Category 3 Stadiums] | fullname = Georgios Karaiskakis Stadium
(Στάδιο Γεώργιος Καραϊσκάκης) | location = [[Piraeus]], [[Attica]], [[Greece]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|56|46.21|N|23|39|52.33|E|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = 1895 | opened = 1896 | renovated = 1964, 2004 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hellenic Olympic Committee]] | operator = [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] | surface = Hybrid Grass | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]] 60,000,000 | architect = Stelios Aghiostratitis | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = [[Neo Phaliron Velodrome]] (1895–1938) | tenants = [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] (1925–1984, 1989–1997, 2004–present)
[[Ethnikos Piraeus F.C.|Ethnikos Piraeus]] (1924–2000)
[[Greece national football team|Greek national football team]] (2004–2008),(2010–2017)
[[Greece women's national football team]] (2008-2017) | capacity = 32,115 {{cite web |url=http://www.superleaguegreece.net/el/teams/team/olympiacos-fc-463/2016-2017-superleague-61/teaminfo|title=Official data for Olympiacos F.C. |publisher=superleaguegreece.net|language=Greek|accessdate=28 September 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.olympiacos.org/page/2180/seating-plan|title=Seating Plan|publisher=olympiacos.org|language=Greek|accessdate=28 September 2016}} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m | scoreboard = [[LED display|LED]] | publictransit = {{OASA icons|M}} {{OASA icons|M1}} {{rint|athens|metro}} [[Faliro metro station]] }} The '''Georgios Karaiskakis Stadium''' ({{lang-el|Στάδιο Γεώργιος Καραϊσκάκης}} {{IPA-el|staðio karaiˈskakis|}}) is a [[Soccer-specific stadium|football stadium]] in the [[Neo Faliro]] area of [[Piraeus]], near [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. It is the home ground of the Greek club [[Olympiacos F.C.]] and is named after [[Georgios Karaiskakis]], a military commander of the [[Greek War of Independence]], who was mortally wounded near the area. ==History== It was used during the [[1896 Summer Olympics]] as the [[Neo Phaliron Velodrome]], where [[France|Frenchman]] [[Paul Masson (cyclist)|Paul Masson]] took the three [[Cycling at the 1896 Summer Olympics|track cycling]] gold medals. It was renovated during the 1960s{{cite web|url=http://www.stadia.gr/karaiskaki/karaiskakiold.html|title= Velodrome and Karaiskaki Stadium (1895 – 1964 – 2003)|publisher=stadia.gr|accessdate=2013-05-28}} and was completely rebuilt in 2004 into a 32,115 capacity, all seater [[stadium]], ready for the [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|football competition]] of the [[2004 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumguide.com/karaiskaki/|title=Karaiskakis Stadium|publisher=stadiumguide.com|accessdate=2013-05-28}}[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2004/or2004b.pdf 2004 Summer Olympics official report.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080819195306/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2004/or2004b.pdf |date=19 August 2008 }} Volume 2. p. 324. The stadium was totally demolished and built again from the beginning, facing a different direction. This complete reconstruction took a record time of only 14 months, finishing just in time for the Olympic Games. After the last deal ended in 1998, Olympiacos is using the stadium once again, on a 49-year lease from [[2003-04 in Greek football|2003]] until 2052 and is traditionally identified as the club's true home. In 2002, the president and owner of Olympiacos [[Socratis Kokkalis]], when announced the project to rebuild Karaiskakis, expressed his wish for the new stadium to be also used by Ethnikos F.C., if they wanted, as Karaiskakis is the historic home of both Olympiacos and Ethnikos. Therefore, in the contract signed by the Hellenic Olympic Committee, the owner of the stadium, and Olympiacos, a clause was included, stating that should Ethnikos wish to return to the stadium, they may do so without sharing any significant maintenance or other stadium-related costs, as those are covered by Olympiacos. As of the 2010/11 season though, Ethnikos has not yet opted to do so. The ticket sales average higher than any team's in recent decades for the [[Super League Greece]] history (rarely have they dropped under the 5,000 mark) and are not expected to drop in the foreseeable future. Sales for national team matches had also been higher, but this was for the most part due to [[Greece national football team|Greece's]] success in the [[Euro 2004]]. As of 2008 and after Greece's disappointing [[Euro 2008]] performance, the attendance of national team matches dropped drastically, leading the Ministry of Sport to change the venue to [[Heraklion|Heraklion, Crete]]. In June 2005, Karaiskakis stadium hosted a movie theatre (''Ciné Karaiskakis'') with a cinema screen that is 20 m long and 10 m wide, operating daily between 9 and 11 p.m. (6 and 8 p.m. UTC) and later, every weekend. The movie screen featured movies including ''[[Batman Begins]]'' and others. The stadium operated as a movie theatre for the last time on Saturday 13 August 2005. ==The Gate 7 Tragedy== {{Main article|Karaiskakis Stadium disaster}} Twenty-one supporters of [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] lost their lives in "Gate 7" (Θύρα 7) of the stadium, after a game between [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] and [[AEK Athens FC]] (that ended 6–0), on 8 February 1981; an incident widely known as the [[Karaiskaki Stadium disaster]]. In memory of this event, at the tribune where Gate 7 is now, twenty-one seats are black colored instead of red, shaping the number "7". A monument on the eastern side of the stadium bears the names of the twenty-one supporters killed on that day in the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.olympiacos.org/en/stadium-gate-7|title=Karaiskaki Stadium History|publisher=olympiacos.org|accessdate=2013-05-28}} ==Stadium features== [[File:Image Olympiacos Chelsea CL0708 2.jpg|260px|thumb|Olympiacos vs [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] during [[UEFA Champions League 2007-08]]]] Karaiskakis Stadium is classified as a 4-star football stadium by the [[UEFA]] organisation, allowing it to host the UEFA Europa League Final if chosen. It hosts 40 VIP lounges and suites, that can hold up to 474[http://www.olympiacos.org/en/hospitality] persons, a press conference hall, that can hold up to 130 seats, 200 seats for press and media coverage, an entire shopping mall, with restaurants, cafés, retail and clothing stores and a gym. The stadium also hosts [http://www.olympiacos.org/en/olympiacos-museum Olympiacos Museum], dedicated not only to the history of the football club, but to the history of all the departments of the multiple European title-winning multi-sport club [[Olympiacos CFP]]. There are 10 automated ticket selling machines around the stadium enabling reservations through the internet or by phone. There is no extra charge for the parking area, which takes up to 1,000[http://www.olympiacos.org/hospitality] cars. Due to its design, the stadium's tribunes have the ability to empty within 7 minutes. The stadium also has restaurants and stores opened during concerts and games and sometimes open with the daily general timetable of most Greek stores and shops. The stadium is easily accessed through the [[Athens Mass Transit System]], at the station "Faliro", which is about 15 minutes from Athens city centre, at the "Omonia" square station and also through Athens driving routes, which is 8 km, about 15 minutes from downtown [[Athens]]. ==Concerts== [[Rihanna]], [[Aerosmith]], [[Evanescence]], [[50 Cent]], [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]], [[Whitesnake]], [[Imiskoumbria]], [[Def Leppard]] and [[Sex Pistols]] have performed at the stadium.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} ==Other names of the stadium== Although the official name of the stadium is [[Georgios Karaiskakis]], however the stadium is known with other names too *'''Naos''': "Temple", by Olympiakos fans or '''Tigani''': "Frying pan"Frying pan is the home utensil where the anchovies (=γαύροι) are baked, as they are called Olympiakos fans, by Greek football fans ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Karaiskaki stadium}} *[http://www.karaiskaki.gr/ Karaiskaki Stadium official website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090216123603/http://www.picable.com/People/Sports/Soccer/Olympiacos-Karaiskaki.368231 photo of Karaiskaki during a game] *[http://stadia.gr/karaiskaki/karaiskaki.html Information and photos of Karaiskaki Stadium (Greek)] *[http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=28e269c69dc0dab3c493cfff29cc24ce Karaiskaki model on Google 3D Warehouse] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[UEFA Cup Winners Cup]]
[[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup finals|Final Venue]]| before=''[[Prater Stadium]]''
''[[Vienna]]''| after=''[[Camp Nou]]''
''[[Barcelona]]''| years='''[[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup 1970-71|1971]]''' }} {{s-end}} {{Olympiacos}} {{Olympiacos F.C.}} {{2004 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues football}} {{Superleague Greece venues}} {{European Athletics Championships stadiums}} {{coord|37|56|47.21|N|23|39|51.54|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Venues of the 2004 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic football venues]] [[Category:Olympiacos F.C.]] [[Category:Ethnikos Piraeus F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in Greece]] [[Category:Sports venues in Piraeus]] [[Category:Atromitos Piraeus F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1896]] [[Category:1896 establishments in Greece]]

{{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Kiremitliktepe
Türk Telekom Ski Jumping Towers | nickname = | image = [[File:Erzurum Kiremitliktepe Kayakla Atlama Kuleleri3.jpg|200px]] | caption = The K-95 /left) and K-125 (right) ski jumping towers at Kiremitliktepe, Erzurum. | location = | city = [[Erzurum]] | country = [[Turkey]] | coordinates = {{coordinates|39.89323|N|41.25202|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | operator = Erzurum GSİM | opened = September 2010 | k-spot = {{ubl|125 m |95 m }} | hill size = {{ubl|HS140 (K-125) |HS109 (K-95) }} | hill record = {{ubl|143.5 m (K-125) |{{flagicon|SLO}} [[Matej Dobovsek]], 2011-01-29, UNI |112.0 m (K-95) |{{flagicon|POL}} [[Klemens Murańka]], 2012-02-23, JWSC }} | capacity = 10,000 | olympics = | world championships = | local championships = }} {{Location map | Turkey | label = Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump | label_size = | caption = Location of Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump in Turkey | alt = | position = left | background = | mark = Ski jumping pictogram.svg | lat_deg = 39.89323 | lat_min = | lat_sec = | lat_dir= N | lon_deg = 41.25202 | lon_min = | lon_sec = | lon_dir= E | width = 250 }} The '''Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump''' ({{lang-tr|Kiremitliktepe Kayakla Atlama Kuleleri}}), or officially '''Türk Telekom Ski Jumping Towers''', is a [[ski jumping]] venue located on the Kiremitlik Hill at the base of [[Palandöken Mountain]] just southwest of [[Erzurum]] in eastern [[Turkey]]. Completed in September 2010, the complex consists of a large hill (K-125) and a normal hill (K-95) jumping tower, as well as three additional smaller slopes of K-65, K-40 and K-20 for training purposes and for use by young jumpers.{{cite web |url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/TUR-Turkey/Erzurum/0444-Kiremitliktepe/ |publisher=Ski Jumping Hill Archive |title=Erzurum Kiremitliktepe-TürkTelekom Ski Jumping Towers |accessdate=2013-04-23 }} ==Design and construction== The construction of the ski jumping center was part of a project of the Ministry of Youth and Sports and the [[Turkey Ski Federation]] that was needed for the realization of the [[2011 Winter Universiade]] in Erzurum. The ski jumping facility was designed in [[modern architecture|modernist style]] by the [[Slovenia|Slovene]] architecture firm Atelje S, partner of the co-contractor MANA Original company from the same country, which won the project's international request for tender along with the Turkish Sarıdağlar construction company in March 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.atelje-s.si/en/node/38 |publisher=Atelje S |title=skakalni center turčija |accessdate=2013-04-24 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.manaoriginal.eu/EE/index.php/novice/turk_telekom_ski_jumping_center_in_erzurum |publisher=MANA Original |title=Turk Telekom Ski Jumping Center in Erzurum |accessdate=2013-04-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130701110839/http://www.manaoriginal.eu/EE/index.php/novice/turk_telekom_ski_jumping_center_in_erzurum |archivedate=2013-07-01 |df= }} Erzurum is located on a high plateau at {{convert|1950|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Height above mean sea level|AMSL]] in [[Eastern Anatolia Region]]. The Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump, situated on the highway {{TUR-D|950}} about {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}} southwest of the city, is at the base of Palandöken Mountain that rise up to {{convert| 3271|m|ft|abbr=on}} altitude. The center with five ski jumping slopes covers an area of {{convert|30|ha|acre|abbr=on}}. The two Olympic-size towers has cylindrical structures at the top. The {{convert|43|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall main tower has five ring structures on it with the colors of [[Olympic symbols|Olympic rings]] symbolizing the Olympic sprit. Atop the main tower, a restaurant is situated. The construction, carried out by the Sarıdağlar company, was completed within ten months, and the sport complex opened in September 2010. It cost [[euro sign|€]]20 million. The venue was renamed in January 2011 after the Turkish telecommunications company [[Türk Telekom]], the main sponsor of the 2011 Winter Universiade. Its new name will be lasting until 2016.{{cite news |url=http://www.sabah.com.tr/Ekonomi/2011/01/07/kulenin_adi_turk_telekom_oldu |newspaper=[[Sabah (newspaper)|Sabah]] |title=Kulenin adı Türk Telekom oldu |date=2011-01-07 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-04-24 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.erzurum2011.gov.tr/haberler/382-kulelerin-adi-artik-turk-telekom |publisher=Erzurum 2011 |title=Kulelerin Adı Artık Türk Telekom... |date=2011-01-10 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114030419/http://erzurum2011.gov.tr/haberler/382-kulelerin-adi-artik-turk-telekom |archivedate=2011-01-14 |df= }} ==Facilities== [[File:Erzurum Kiremitliktepe Kayakla Atlama Kuleleri2.jpg|200px|thumb|K125 inrun (left), K-95 inrun (right) and landing area with bleachers around as seen from the main tower of Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump.]] The multi-purpose facility allows organization of ski jumping events at highest level year around. The high-tech ice-ceramic track inruns and plastic matt covered ski-jump landing area enable equal competition conditions in winter season as well as during the rest of the year irrespectively of the weather. The venue has 10,000 spectator capacity. The complex offers accommodation in the hotel near the large hill and in the bungalows on top of the center, and catering in the restaurant atop the main ski jump tower. There is a gym hall for training, and saunas and massage pools for relaxation. Also during the time when no competitions are held, the facility attracts local population and tourists for recreation activities and social events at the hotel restaurant and the restaurant atop the 43m-high tower, which offers a panoramic view of the entire city. ===Large hill=== The large hill has a [[K-point]] of 125 and a [[hill size]] of 140 with a {{convert|43.47|m|ft|abbr=on}} high jumping tower. It has a {{convert|99|m|ft|abbr=on}} long inrun with an angle of 35°, a take-off angle of 11°, which is {{convert|7|m|ft|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|3|m|ft|abbr=on}} high. The slope for the landing is 34.57°. The total height is {{convert|136.8|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Hill record was set with 143.5 m by [[Matej Dobovsek]] from Slovenia at the 2011 Winter Universiade on January 29, 2011. ===Normal hill=== The normal hill's K-point is 95 and hill size 109. It has a jumping tower of {{convert|20.98|m|ft|abbr=on}} height. The inrun is {{convert|88|m|ft|abbr=on}} long at an angle of 35°. The take-off length is {{convert|6.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, the height {{convert|2.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} with an angle of 10.5°. The landing's angle is 34.25°. The normal hill has a total height of {{convert|107.1|m|ft|abbr=on}}. [[Aleksander Zniszczoł]] from [[Poland]] set a hill record with 111.5 m at the FIS Junior World Ski Championships on February 21, 2012. Women's record belongs to [[Japan]]ese [[Sara Takanashi]] with 110.5 m set at same event on the same day. ==Events hosted== The first international event, which took place at the Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump, was the [[FIS Ski Jumping Continental Cup]] on December 18-19, 2010. The next competition was the Winter Universiade held from January 28 to February 3, 2011. The venue hosted again the FIS Ski Jumping Continental Cup's ski jumping event in December 2011 and [[Nordic combined]] event in January 2012. The [[2012 FIS Junior World Ski Championships]] were held at the ski jumping facility from February 22 to 25. ==2014 landslide== On July 15, 2014, there was a huge [[landslide]] on the Kiremitlik Hill with the result that hills were damaged. On investigation it was noted that the construction completely lacked foundations, the ski slopes and seating being laid directly onto bare earth. Due to this accident, the future of the Kiremitliktepe Ski Jump and also of ski jumping in Turkey is doubtful.{{cite news|url=http://skokinews.com/2014/07/15/znacznie-uszkodzona-skocznia-w-tureckim-erzurum/ |publisher=SKOKInews.com |title=Znacznie uszkodzona skocznia w tureckim Erzurum! |date=2014-07-15 |language=Polish |accessdate=2014-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718011843/http://skokinews.com/2014/07/15/znacznie-uszkodzona-skocznia-w-tureckim-erzurum/ |archivedate=2014-07-18 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Ski jumping in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Erzurum]] [[Category:Ski jumping venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Turkey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Erzurum Province]]

She participated at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web|title=2003 World Gymnastics Championships athletes - Krisztina Szarka|url=http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/000002030000FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF01|work=longinestiming.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}} ==References== ==External links== *http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/sz/krisztina-szarka-1.html *http://gymnast.bplaced.com/AG/Szarka.htm *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zaGsy9E_4A {{Hungary-sport-stub}} {{Hungary-bio-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Szarka, Krisztina}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hungarian female artistic gymnasts]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Gymnasts at the 2004 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic gymnasts of Hungary]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Lake Macquarie Regional Football Facility | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = Speers Point, NSW, Australia | coordinates = {{Coord|32|57|35|S|151|37|8.2|E|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:AUS}} | broke_ground = 28 March 2014<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lakemac.com.au/page.aspx?pid=62&vid=1&nid=2260&npt=details|work=Lake Macquarie City Council|title=Construction underway for $11.3 million Lake Macquarie Football Facility|date=28 March 2014}}</ref> | built = 2014 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|2014|11|26}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Northern NSW Football and the NSW State Government Hunter Infrastructure & Investment Fund | operator = [[Northern NSW Football]] | surface = | scoreboard = | construction_cost = [[Australian Dollars|AUD]] $11.3 million (2014) | suites = | architect = ADW Johnson Pty Ltd <ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.lakemac.com.au/downloads/14DAE004F7FCE49850727D00552F57660811F4FB.pdf |title=Community Newsletter 2|publisher=lakemac.com.au}}</ref> | project_manager = ADW Johnson Pty Ltd | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = | hosts = | website = }}
The '''Lake Macquarie Regional Football Facility (LMRFF)''' is a football facility located in [[Speers Point]], NSW.
Developed in 2014, it consists of: * 2 full-size synthetic football fields, * 10 five-a-side football fields, * an administration building, * a 120-space vehicle parking area and associated infrastructure.
==FFA Cup==
LMRFF is the host for the [[NNSW FFA Cup Qualifying]] final rounds. The inaugural event at the facility is to be played on the weekend of 20–21 June 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://northernnswfootball.com.au/westfield-ffa-cup-qualification-weekend-participants-determined/|title=Westfield FFA Cup Qualification Weekend Participants Determined|work=www.northernnswfootball.com.au/|date=18 May 2015|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref>
==Newcastle Jets==
On May 21 2015, it was announced that the LMRFF would become the training facility for [[A-League]] team, the [[Newcastle Jets FC|Newcastle Jets]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbnnews.com.au/2015/05/21/ffa-move-in-to-start-new-future-at-jets/|title=FFA Move In To Start New Future At Jets|work=[[NBN Television|NBN News]]|date=21 May 2015|accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> This coincided with [[Football Federation Australia|FFA]] taking ownership of the club. The team had previously trained at Ray Watt Oval at the [[University of Newcastle (Australia)|University of Newcastle]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.lakemac.com.au/downloads/51F573E06CAE62D085BB45D1C15ADF4C1EBD1121.jpg], Project Plans * [http://northernnswfootball.com.au/about-us/lake-macquarie-regional-football-facility/] Lake Macquarie Regional Football Facility

The club was founded in 1945 and its colors are black and white. Their home stadium, the [[Stade Boualem Bourada]], has a capacity of some 3,000 spectators. The The club is currently playing in the [[Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur]]. ==External links== * {{fr icon}} [http://www.lnf.org.dz/d1/narbr.htm LNF Profile] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.dzfoot.com/clubs/clubs.php?club_id=89 DZFoot Profile] {{Algerian Championnat National 2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reghaia, NARB}} [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1954]] [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Algiers Province|Narb Reghaia]] [[Category:1954 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

{{About|the arena formerly known as the Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum Arena|the neighboring baseball park and football stadium with a similar name|Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Oracle Arena | nickname = Oakland Coliseum Arena | logo_image = [[File:Oracle Arena.svg|150px]] | image = [[File:Theoraclearena.jpg|300px]] | caption = | address = 7000 Coliseum Way | location = [[Oakland, California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|45|1|N|122|12|11|W|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=inline,title}} | publictransit = {{bus icon}} '''[[AC Transit]]''': [[List of AC Transit routes#Local service|45]], [[List of AC Transit routes#Local service|46]], [[List of AC Transit routes#Local service|46L]], {{Air icon}} [[All Nighter (night bus service)#Routes|73]], [[List of AC Transit routes#Local service|90]], [[List of AC Transit routes#Local service|98]], [[List of AC Transit routes#Special service|356]], [[List of AC Transit routes#School service|646]], [[List of AC Transit routes#School service|657]], [[All Nighter (night bus service)#Routes|805]]
{{bus icon|12px}} '''[[Alameda County, California|Alameda County]] [[East Oakland, Oakland, California|East Oakland]] Shuttle'''
{{rint|us|amtrak}} '''[[Amtrak]]''': ''[[Capitol Corridor]]'' at [[Oakland Coliseum station|Oakland Coliseum]]
{{rail-interchange|bart}} '''[[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]]''' : {{Rail color box|system=BART|line=OAK}}{{Rail color box|system=BART|line=Blue}}{{Rail color box|system=BART|line=Orange}}{{Rail color box|system=BART|line=Green}} at [[Oakland Coliseum station|Coliseum]]
{{bus icon|12px}} '''[[Bay Farm Island, Alameda, California|Harbor Bay]] Business Park Shuttle''' | broke_ground = April 15, 1964 | opened = November 9, 1966 | renovated = 1996–1997 | owner = Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum Authority | operator = [[Anschutz Entertainment Group|AEG]] | construction_cost = US$24 million {{small|(original)}}{{cite web|url=https://digital.lib.washington.edu/architect/structures/7179/|title=PCAD - the Pacific Coast Architecture Database - Home|website=digital.lib.washington.edu}}
$121 million {{small|(1996–97 renovation)}} | architect = [[Skidmore, Owings and Merrill]]

The Arena in Oakland (1997–2005)
Oakland Arena (2005–2006) | tenants = [[Golden State Warriors]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1966–1967, 1971–2019)
[[San Francisco Seals (ice hockey)|California Seals]] ([[Western Hockey League (minor pro)|WHL]]) (1966–1967)
[[Oakland Oaks (ABA)|Oakland Oaks]] ([[American Basketball Association|ABA]]) (1967–1969)
[[California Golden Seals]] ([[National Hockey League|NHL]]) (1967–1976)
[[San Francisco Golden Gaters]] ([[World TeamTennis|WTT]]) (1974–1978)
[[Golden Bay Earthquakes]] ([[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]]/[[Major Indoor Soccer League (1978–1992)|MISL]]) (1982–1984)
[[Oakland Skates]] ([[Roller Hockey International|RHI]]) (1993–1995)
[[California Golden Bears]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (part-time 1966–1996, full-time 1997–1999) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 19,596
[[Concert]]: 20,000
[[Ice hockey]]: 13,601 (1966–1997), 17,200 (1997–present) }} '''Oracle Arena''' is an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Oakland, California]], United States, and is the home of the [[Golden State Warriors]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). The arena opened in 1966 and is the oldest arena in the NBA. From its opening until 1996 it was known as the '''Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum Arena'''. After a major renovation completed in 1997, the arena was renamed '''The Arena in Oakland''' until 2005 and '''Oakland Arena''' from 2005 to 2006. It is often referred to as the '''Oakland Coliseum Arena''' as it is located adjacent to the [[Oakland–Alameda County Coliseum]]. Oracle Arena seats 19,596 fans for basketball and 17,200 for ice hockey. ==History== ===Home franchises=== The arena has been the home of the [[Golden State Warriors]]{{cite web|url=http://basketball.ballparks.com/NBA/GoldenStateWarriors/index.htm|title=Oracle Arena|first=BALLPARKS.com by Munsey and|last=Suppes|website=basketball.ballparks.com}} since the [[1971–72 NBA season|1971–72 season]], except the one-year hiatus while the arena was undergoing renovations. It had been used by the Warriors intermittently as early as [[1966–67 NBA season|1966]]. The [[California Golden Bears]] of the [[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]] played the 1997–98 and 1998–99 seasons at the arena while their primary home, Harmon Gym, was being renovated into [[Haas Pavilion]]. For some years before then, the Bears played occasional games against popular non-conference opponents at the arena. Oracle Arena has been home to Warriors playoff games in 1972, 1973, 1975, 1976, 1977, 1987, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1994, 2007, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018.{{cite web|url=https://basketball.realgm.com/nba/teams/Golden-State-Warriors/9/Playoff-History|title=Golden State Warriors Playoff History - RealGM|website=basketball.realgm.com}} It hosted the [[2015 NBA Finals|2015]], [[2016 NBA Finals|2016]], [[2017 NBA Finals|2017]], and the [[2018 NBA Finals]], where the Warriors won in 2015, 2017, and 2018. The 2015 victory was the first time since 1975 the Warriors won the title; however, Games 2 and 3 of the [[1975 NBA Finals]] were played in the [[Cow Palace]] as the Coliseum was unavailable. The 2017 victory was the first time that a San Francisco Bay Area team won a title in their home venue since the [[Oakland Athletics]] in the [[1974 World Series]]. The arena's first tenants were the [[San Francisco Seals (ice hockey)|California Seals]] of the [[Western Hockey League (minor pro)|Western Hockey League]], who moved across [[San Francisco Bay|the bay]] from the [[Cow Palace]] in 1966. The owners of the San Francisco Seals had been awarded an expansion franchise in the [[National Hockey League]] on the condition they move out the Cow Palace and into the then-new Oakland Coliseum Arena. The team changed its operating name from San Francisco Seals to California Seals in order to draw fans from both San Francisco and Oakland. The Seals franchise continued to play at the arena after having transferred to the NHL, until the team moved to Cleveland after the [[1975–76 NHL season]].{{cite web|url=http://hockey.ballparks.com/NHL/CaliforniaSeals/index.htm|title=Oakland/Alameda Coliseum|first=BALLPARKS.com by Munsey and|last=Suppes|website=hockey.ballparks.com}} The Coliseum also hosted the [[American Basketball Association]]'s [[Oakland Oaks (ABA)|Oakland Oaks]] (1967–1969), a charter member of the new ABA in 1967. The Oaks signed [[San Francisco Warriors]] star [[Rick Barry]] away from the rival [[National Basketball Association]] in 1968. The team was owned by entertainer [[Pat Boone]] and also had stars [[Larry Brown (basketball)|Larry Brown]] and [[Doug Moe]] on its roster. Brown and Barry are in the Basketball Hall of Fame. After a 22–56 record in their first season, the Oaks went 60–18 during the regular season in 1968–69. The Oaks then defeated the [[Denver Rockets]], [[New Orleans Buccaneers]] and finally the [[Indiana Pacers]] in the playoffs to capture the ABA Championship. However, the team was plagued by poor attendance and Boone sold the team following their ABA Championship. They were relocated to Washington and became the [[Washington Caps]].{{cite web|url=http://www.remembertheaba.com/Oakland-Oaks.html|title=Remember the ABA: Oakland Oaks|website=www.remembertheaba.com}} The Bay Bombers ([[Roller derby|Roller Derby]], 1966–1973) as well as the [[Golden Bay Earthquakes]] of the [[Major Indoor Soccer League (1978–92)|original MISL]] during the 1982–83 season and the [[Oakland Skates]], a professional [[roller hockey]] team active from 1993 to 1995, all played there. WWE also holds professional wrestling matches at the arena. ===Renovation=== Over three decades, the arena grew outdated, lacking the luxuries of newer ones. With just over 15,000 seats, it was one of the smallest venues in the league. Rather than building a new arena in Oakland, San Francisco or [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the decision was made to proceed with a US$121 million renovation that involved tearing out much of interior and building a new seating bowl within the existing structure. The original walls, roof and foundation remained intact, similar to the rebuild of [[KeyArena]] in [[Seattle]]. The renovation began in mid-1996 and was completed in time for the Warriors return in the fall of [[1997–98 Golden State Warriors season|1997]] (they played the [[1996–97 Golden State Warriors season|previous season]] at the [[San Jose Arena]], home of the NHL's [[San Jose Sharks|Sharks]]). Included in the renovation was a new center overhead [[LED]] scoreboard and 360-degree fascia display. The new configuration seats 19,596 for [[basketball]] and 17,200 for [[ice hockey]]. ===The Oracle=== On October 20, 2006, the Golden State Warriors and [[Oracle Corporation]] announced that the Oakland Arena would be known as The Oracle for a 10-year term. A press conference was held on October 30.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/warriors/news/Oracle_Formal_Announcement.html|title=Warriors, ORACLE Formally Announce Naming Rights Agreement For ORACLE Arena - Golden State Warriors|publisher=}} "The O", as it is referred to, continued to be managed by Oakland–Alameda County Authority (JPA) and SMG. The JPA approved the deal at its November 10 meeting.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/warriors/news/Oracle_Naming_Rights_Agreement.html|title=Golden State Warriors, Oracle Reach Arena Naming Rights Agreement - Golden State Warriors|publisher=}} Oracle Arena has, at least since 2013, been one of the loudest arenas in the NBA. It is called "Roaracle" because of the painfully high decibel levels sometimes generated at Warriors games. The Warriors will play their final regular season home game on April 7, 2019 against the [[Los Angeles Clippers]] (pending any playoff games if they qualify, which they may), and the team's lease is set to expire by the end of June 2019.[https://www.goldenstateofmind.com/2013/5/21/4351786/hey-roaracle-i-heard-you-are-a-wild-one-said-warriors-jarrett-jack-and-other-veteran-free-agents "Hey Roaracle"], May 21, 2013, Retrieved May 26, 2018 ===Attendance records=== [[Image:GSW Vs Utah.jpg|thumb|250px|A record-breaking crowd watching the Warriors in the 2007 NBA Playoffs.]] On May 13, 2007, 20,679 fans watched the Warriors lose to the [[Utah Jazz]] 115–101 in Game 4 of the [[2007 NBA Playoffs|Western Conference semifinals]]. This was the highest attendance in the Warriors' 61-year history. That record lasted until December 14, [[2007–08 NBA season|2007]], when the Warriors hosted the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and packed 20,705 into the Arena to set a new franchise attendance record. The record was again broken on February 20, 2008, when the arena hosted 20,711 for the Warriors-[[Boston Celtics|Celtics]] game.{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2008/02/20/sports/s222359S25.DTL&type=sports | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210082307/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2008%2F02%2F20%2Fsports%2Fs222359S25.DTL&type=sports | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2008-12-10 | title=Baron Davis hits last-second jumper in Warriors' 119–117 win over Celtics | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | df= }} This record was set yet again on April 10, 2008, when Oracle Arena hosted 20,737 fans in a Warriors loss to the [[Denver Nuggets]].{{Cite news| url =http://bleacherreport.com/articles/440114-next-for-the-warriors-the-oakland-warriors-or-san-francisco-bound|title= Next for the Warriors: The Oakland Warriors? Or San Francisco Bound?|author= Jeff Maus|publisher= [[Bleacher Report]] |date = August 20, 2010 }} By the end of the 2016–17 regular season, Oracle had sold out 230 consecutive home games, a streak that continued throughout the team's playoff run. Oracle drew over 18,000 people per game for 12 straight seasons.{{Cite news| url =http://www.nba.com/warriors/news/warriors-230-straight-sellouts-20170412/|title= Warriors Conclude 2016-17 Regular Season with 230 Consecutive Sellouts|author= |publisher= [[www.nba.com/warriors]] |date = April 12, 2017 }} ===The Grateful Dead=== The [[Grateful Dead]] played more concerts (66) at this venue than at any other,{{cite web|url=http://www.setlists.net/|title=The SetList Program - Grateful Dead Setlists, Listener Experiences, and Statistics|website=www.setlists.net}}{{cite web|url=http://www.deadlists.com/deadlists/venues.asp?order=4|title=venues|website=www.deadlists.com}} and their December 16, 1992 concert at the arena was released as ''[[Dick's Picks Volume 27]]'', along with bonus tracks from their December 17, 1992 concert at the arena. ==Future== Early in 2013, the Warriors announced they would build a new arena in San Francisco and move back to the city.{{cite news|last=Matier|first=Phillip|title=Warriors to build new arena, move back to S.F.|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/matier-ross/article/Warriors-to-build-new-arena-move-back-to-S-F-3575560.php|accessdate=8 May 2014|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle (SF Gate)|date=February 15, 2013}} It was originally suggested that the arena would be built on the decaying sites of Piers 30–32 near the foot of the [[San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge|Bay Bridge]], but the plan was met with opposition due to concerns about traffic, environmental impacts and obstruction of views.{{cite news |first=Heather|last=Knight Perrigan|authorlink=|title=Golden State Warriors owners make a risky play|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2012/05/22/MNKD1OLCVJ.DTL|accessdate=May 22, 2012|work=The San Francisco Chronicle|date=May 22, 2012}} In April 2014, the Warriors purchased 12-acres in [[Mission Bay, San Francisco|Mission Bay]] as the site for a new 18,000-seat arena planned to open for the 2018–19 NBA season.{{cite news|last=Cote|first=John|title=Warriors shift arena plans to Mission Bay|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Warriors-ditch-Piers-30-32-for-Mission-Bay-arena-5418579.php|accessdate=1 April 2016|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle (SF Gate)|date=April 22, 2014}} The new location eliminated the need for voter approval, which would have been required for the original site, though it had been unanimously approved by the San Francisco Supervisors in November 2012.{{cite news| url=http://blog.sfgate.com/cityinsider/2012/11/20/board-gives-warriors-arena-initial-green-light/ | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=Board gives Warriors' arena initial green light}} Because of delays due to litigation filed by arena opponents it is now planned to open at the start of the 2019–20 NBA season.{{cite news|title=GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS DELAY OPENING OF SAN FRANCISCO ARENA TO 2019|url=http://abc7news.com/sports/golden-state-warriors-delay-opening-of-sf-arena-to-2019/1160981/|accessdate=1 April 2016|newspaper=ABC 7 News|date=January 15, 2016}} The new arena will be named the [[Chase Center (arena)|Chase Center]].{{cite news|last=Dineen|first=J.K.|title=Warriors arena to be named Chase Center — bank buys naming rights|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Warriors-arena-to-be-named-Chase-Center-bank-6788844.php|accessdate=1 April 2016|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle (SF Gate)|date=28 January 2016}} ==Seating capacity== [[Image:Oracle Arena 2011-12-17.jpg|thumb|250px|An interior view of Oracle Arena.]] The seating capacity for basketball has expanded from 13 to 19 thousand in over a half-century of use:{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/warriors/photos/1112_MediaGuide.pdf|title=2011-2012 Golden State Warriors Media Guide|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="{{NBA color '''1st:''' €40,000 }} The '''Prix Bertrand du Breuil''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 3]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[France]] open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged four years or older. It is run at [[Chantilly Racecourse|Chantilly]] over a distance of 1,600 metres (about 1 mile), and it is scheduled to take place each year in June. ==History== The earliest version of the event was established at Chantilly in 1852. Its prize money was originally provided by the [[Chemin de Fer du Nord]], a railway company in northern France and the race was titled the '''Prix de Chemin du Fer du Nord'''. The first running was a 1,200-metre flat race for two-year-olds, and in the following years it was a 2,400-metre event over [[Hurdling (horse race)|hurdles]]. It reverted to being a flat race in 1856, when it became a 3,200-metre contest for horses aged three or older. The Chemin de Fer du Nord continued to provide the total prize money until 1910. Thereafter, it contributed a partial amount each year until 1937. The funding discontinued when the regional railways merged to form the [[SNCF]]. The present Prix du Chemin de Fer du Nord was created in 1933, when its distance was cut to 1,400 metres. It was cancelled in 1940, and for the next two years it was held at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]]. It was run at [[Maisons-Laffitte Racecourse|Maisons-Laffitte]] in 1943, and was cancelled again in 1944. Another spell at Longchamp began in 1945. The race was extended to 1,700 metres in 1950. It returned to Chantilly and reverted to 1,400 metres in 1955. The minimum age was raised to four in 1967, and the distance was increased to 1,600 metres in 1972. The event was staged at Maisons-Laffitte in 1997 and 1998, and its current period at Chantilly began in 1999. It is now held on the same day as the [[Prix de Diane]]. In 2013 the race was renamed in memory of Bertrand du Breuil (1926-2011), the last president of the Societe d'Encouragemment, forerunner of [[France Galop]]. ==Records==
'''Most successful horse (2 wins):''' * Menetrier – ''1948, 1949'' * Spirito del Vento – ''2007, 2008'' ---- '''Leading [[jockey]] (7 wins):''' * [[Freddy Head]] – ''Apataki (1966), Regent Street (1969), My Friend Paul (1973), Rostov (1980), Big John (1982), Pluralisme (1984), Pink (1985)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (7 wins):''' * [[André Fabre]] – ''Mill Native (1988), French Stress (1989), Kingsalsa (2000), Cacique (2005), Apsis (2006), [[Byword (horse)|Byword]] (2011), Fintry (2015)'' ---- '''Leading owner (4 wins):''' * [[Khalid ibn Abdullah|Khalid Abdullah]] – ''Cacique (2005), Apsis (2006), Byword (2011). Mainsail (2013)''

revision.text:
'''Sport management''' is the field of [[business]] dealing with [[sports]] and [[recreation]]. Some examples of sport managers include the [[front office]] system in [[professional sports]], [[college sports]] managers, recreational sport managers, [[sports marketing]], [[event management]], [[facility management]], sports economics, sport finance, and sports information.
Bachelor's and master's degrees in sport management are offered by many colleges and universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://johancruyffinstitute.com/en/sport-management/|title=Sport Management Academic Programs - Johan Cruyff Institute|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Johan Cruyff Institute|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nassm.com/Programs/AcademicPrograms|title=Academic Programs|publisher=North American Society for Sport Management|accessdate=28 April 2016}}</ref> A number of classes outside sport management may be relevant to the field, including; classes in management, marketing, business administration, economics, and accounting. Internships may also open opportunities within the field.
In America, jobs in sport management include working for professional programs like the [[NFL]], [[NBA]], [[MLB]], [[NHL]], [[MLS]], and other professional or non-professional sport leagues in terms of marketing, health, and promotions.
==See also== *[[Sport industry]] *[[Sports marketing]] *[[Sports agent]]
==References== <references />
==Further reading== * {{cite encyclopedia |last1= Tollison |first1=Robert |authorlink1= Robert Tollison |editor= [[David R. Henderson]] (ed.) |encyclopedia=[[Concise Encyclopedia of Economics]] |title=Sportometrics |url=http://www.econlib.org/library/Enc/Sportometrics.html |year=2008 |edition= 2nd |publisher=[[Library of Economics and Liberty]] |location=Indianapolis |isbn=978-0865976658 |oclc=237794267}} * Drayer, Joris, Stephen L. Shapiro, and Seoki Lee. "Dynamic ticket pricing in sport: an agenda for research and practice." Sport Marketing Quarterly 21.3 (2012): 184+

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Swisher Gymnasium | logo_image = | image = | location = On Dolphin Drive east of intersection of University Oaks Drive and University Blvd North [[Jacksonville, Florida]] 32211 | coordinates = {{Coord|30|21|01|N|81|36|18|W|type:landmark_region:US-FL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = {{start date|1953}}{{cite web|title=Timeline|url=http://www.ju.edu/aboutju/Pages/Timeline.aspx|publisher=Jacksonville University|accessdate=July 31, 2016}} | opened = | expanded = | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Jacksonville University]] | operator = [[Jacksonville University]] | surface = Multi-surface | suites = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | tenants = [[Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball]]
[[Jacksonville Dolphins|Jacksonville Dolphins women's basketball]] | seating_capacity = 1,360{{cite web|title=2015–16 Men’s Basketball Quick Facts|url=http://www.judolphins.com/sports/mbkb/2015-16/files/2015-16_JU_Mens_BkB_Quick_Facts.pdf|publisher=Jacksonville University Athletics|accessdate=July 31, 2016}}{{cite web|author1=Jeff Elliott|title=Swisher Gymnasium among priorities for JU athletic director Alex Ricker-Gilbert|url=http://jacksonville.com/sports/college/jacksonville-dolphins/2016-06-01/story/swisher-gymnasium-among-priorities-ju-athletic|publisher=The Florida Times-Union|accessdate=July 31, 2016|date=June 1, 2016}} | record_attendance = | website = }} '''Swisher Gymnasium''' is a 1,360-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. Built in 1953, it is currently the home to the [[Jacksonville University]] Dolphins men and women's [[basketball]] [[team]]s. Prior to the 2015–16 season, [[Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball|Jacksonville]] played its home games at both Swisher Gymnasium and the [[Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena]].{{cite web|author1=Garry Smits|title=JU moves all home basketball games to on-campus Swisher Gym|url=http://jacksonville.com/sports/college/jacksonville-dolphins/2015-08-27/story/ju-moves-all-home-basketball-games-campus|publisher=The Florida Times-Union|accessdate=July 31, 2016|date=August 27, 2015}} In addition to athletic contests, [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Lyndon Baines Johnson]] addressed students in 1963 at the gymnasium. Swisher Gymnasium was also used for several concerts including [[Dionne Warwick]] (November 9, 1967), [[Billy Joel]] (March, 1975), and [[K.C. and the Sunshine Band]] (September 7, 1979). Swisher Gymnasium was also a contender as a site for one the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 Presidential Debates]], but was not selected as a finalist.{{cite web|author1=Roger Weeder|title=JU vying to host presidential debate|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/09/16/ju-presidential-debates/32514165/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=July 31, 2016|date=September 16, 2015}}{{cite web|author1=Rhema Thompson|title=Jacksonville University misses on bid to host 2016 presidential debate|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/metro/2015-09-23/story/jacksonville-university-misses-bid-host-2016-general-election-debate|publisher=The Florida Times-Union|accessdate=July 31, 2016|date=September 23, 2015}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] {{Jacksonville University}} {{Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball navbox}} {{Jacksonville Dolphins women's basketball navbox}} {{Atlantic Sun Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Jacksonville attractions}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1953]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Florida]] {{Florida-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox company | name = Fitness Anywhere, LLC | image = TRX-2.jpg | image_caption = A person using a TRX system anchored to a tree | type = Limited Liability Corporation | genre = [[Physical fitness|Fitness]] | foundation = 2005 | founder = Randy Hetrick | location_city = San Francisco | location_country = USA | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | industry = | products = TRX Suspension Trainer and TRX Rip Trainer | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | owner = | company_slogan = | homepage = https://www.trxtraining.com | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''TRX System''', also known as '''Total Resistance exercises''', refers to a specialized form of [[suspension training]] that utilizes equipment developed by former U.S. Navy SEAL [[Randy Hetrick]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=Who We Are|url=https://www.trxtraining.com/discover/who-we-are|website=TRX|publisher=Fitness Anywhere LLC|accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref> TRX is a form of suspension training that uses body weight exercises to develop strength, balance, flexibility and core stability simultaneously. It requires the use of the TRX Suspension Trainer, a performance training tool that leverages gravity and the user’s body weight to complete the exercises.<ref name=":0" /> TRX's designers claim that it draws on research from the military, pro sports, and academic institutions along with experience gathered from the TRX team, who work "with thousands of athletes, coaches, trainers, first responders, subject matter experts, professors, and service members in all branches."<ref name=":0" />
== History == While deployed in Southeast Asia in 1997, Hetrick was looking for a different method of training than the generic push-ups. He uses familiar products–a jiu-jitsu belt and parachute webbing–to create the first version of the TRE Suspension Trainer.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = The Story of TRX {{!}} TRX|url = https://www.trxtraining.com/discover/who-we-are/heritage|website = www.trxtraining.com|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> In 2001, after 14 years as a SEAL Hetrick left the Navy and attended [[Stanford University]] where he earned his MBA. <ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = Ex-Navy SEAL Sells TRX Fitness Gear That ’Enables’ Content Sales|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-03-08/former-navy-seal-sells-trx-fitness-gear-to-enable-content-sales|website = Bloomberg.com|accessdate = 2015-10-13}}</ref> He attended the gym regularly with the hopes of bringing his apparatus to a working prototype by gaining the attention of athletes, coaches and trainers.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Hetrick first established his TRX system at the [http://www.kravmaga-sf.com Krav Maga Fitness Club] on 1455 Bush Street San Francisco with $350,000 from private investors that he met through connections via Stanford and the military.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> He began to sell the line of training equipment known today as TRX. Since 2017, the TRX International Day is celebrated on January 25th{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}}.
==Benefits and criticism==
Supporters of TRX Training claim that it can improve mobility and stability, increase metabolic results, build lean muscle, and develop functional strength.<ref name=":0" /> Other advocates of the system say that you can't help but use your core for stabilization.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|title = Suspension Training: How Risky Is It?|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/01/fashion/01Fitness.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2007-02-01|access-date = 2015-10-26|issn = 0362-4331|first = Nick|last = Burns}}</ref> Hedrick states that, "People who like yoga and Pilates tend to like TRX because there are some crossovers. But it's also great for runners, cyclists, or anyone who is an endurance athlete and wants to have more strength training."<ref>{{Cite web|title = 4 Reasons to Try TRX Suspension Training|url = http://www.popsugar.com/fitness/Why-TRX-Good-Workout-21651496|website = POPSUGAR Fitness|accessdate = 2015-10-26|language = en}}</ref> On the contrary, some analysts worry that the instability of suspension straps could possibly result in injury, especially for those with a history of joint or back injuries, or inadequate core strength.<ref name=":3" /> Fabio Comana, a research scientist at the nonprofit [[American Council on Exercise]], states that suspension training may work for well-conditioned athletes and gym-goers who regularly train their core, however, it is potentially dangerous for those who haven’t built up their core.<ref name=":3" />
==References==
{{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:TRX System}} [[Category:Weight training equipment]] [[Category:Exercise equipment companies]] [[Category:Exercise equipment]] [[Category:Exercise-related trademarks]] 6. ^ [https://www.coretrainingtips.com/what-is-trx/ All about the TRX Training System here]

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox golf facility | name = Trump National Golf Club Westchester | image = Trump NGCW.png | imagesize = 250 | alt = | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|41|08|46|N|73|50|00|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Briarcliff Manor, New York]] | establishment = 1922 | type = Private | owner = [[The Trump Organization]] | operator = <!-- name of organization/company --> | holes = 18 | greens = <!-- type of grass used --> | fairways = <!-- type of grass used --> | tournaments = | website = {{official website}} | course1 = <!-- individual course name, can leave blank if same as article title --> | designer1 = Jim Fazio | par1 = 72 | length1 = 7200 | rating1 = | slope1 = | record1 = | image2 = | imagesize2 = <!-- only used for under 220px and leave off px part --> | caption2 = }} '''Trump National Golf Club Westchester''' is a private [[golf club]] in [[Briarcliff Manor, New York]]. Owned by [[Donald Trump]], the 45th [[President of the United States]], the {{convert|140|acre|ha|sing=on}} course has eighteen holes, with a {{convert|75000|sqft|adj=on}} clubhouse. Founded in 1922 as ''Briarcliff Country Club'', it later operated as ''Briar Hills Country Club'' and ''Briar Hall Golf and Country Club'' before Trump's purchase of the property in 1996. Trump renamed the club to match his [[The Trump Organization#Golf courses|other golf properties]], and after its county, [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]]. He had the clubhouse and course rebuilt for its 2002 reopening; the course was designed by Jim Fazio. Donald Trump served as president over Trump National Golf Club LLC (managing the Westchester club) from August 2000 until January 19, 2017, the day before his inauguration.<ref name="Discl">{{cite web|title=Executive Branch Personnel Public Financial Disclosure Report|publisher=United States Office of Government Ethics|url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3867112-Trump-Financial-Disclosure-2017.html|date=June 16, 2017|accessdate=June 16, 2017}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Briar Hills pool 2.tif|thumb|Briar Hills pool, c. 1940]] The club had its origins around 1895, with Briarcliff founder [[Walter W. Law]]'s private nine-hole course on his estate, which became available to [[Briarcliff Lodge]] guests, and was then known as the Briarcliff Golf Club. In 1922, Devereux Emmet designed a course across the street with eighteen holes, and thus Briarcliff Country Club was founded that year.<ref name="Sale"/><ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=84}} The name was changed in 1927 to avoid confusion, to Briar Hills Country Club.<ref name="1952history"/>{{rp|page=84}}<ref name="MCMA"/> Briar Hills opened in May 1929 with a new clubhouse; construction began in May 1928 and utilized local stones for the building's exterior. The interior was noted for its design and spaciousness.<ref name="1929club"/> In 1936, [[A. W. Tillinghast]] redesigned the course.<ref name="Till"/> In 1948, Henry Law's son Theodore sold the club to local businessmen who renamed it Briar Hall Golf and Country Club.<ref name="MCMA"/> The 1964 [[Metropolitan Open]] was hosted at Briar Hall; Jack Patroni won the championship.<ref name="MOpen"/> In 1980, ownership of the club changed hands again.<ref name="MCMA"/> <!--Briar Hills - A new clubhouse was built, and a new golf course, designed by [[Devereux Emmet]]. For a time, the club utilized a large white house, Elderslie, as its clubhouse.<ref name="Landscape"/>{{rp|page=80}}-->
Henry Law, a son of village founder Walter W. Law, was among Briar Hill's founders.<ref name="Landscape"/>{{rp|page=80}} Among the club's directors were Henry Law and his son Theodore Gilman Law;<ref name="Landscape"/>{{rp|page=80}} [[Gene Sarazen]] was the club's golf professional in 1923-24,<ref name="MCMA"/> followed by [[1952 PGA Championship|1952 PGA Champion]] [[Jim Turnesa]].<ref name="Turnesa"/>
===Trump's purchase and redevelopment=== At the time of Briar Hall's 1996 sale, the club had an 18-hole, {{convert|6313|yard|m|0}} golf course and {{convert|78782|sqft|m2|0}} clubhouse, seven tennis courts, an in-ground swimming pool, pro shop, maintenance building, and pool house.<ref name="Sale"/> Briar Hall had been taken over by the Marine Midland Bank, which then sold the property to Trump.<ref name="Ebsco1"/> Trump bought Briar Hall Country Club for $7.5 million<ref name="Value"/> in the foreclosure in December 1996<ref name="Controversy"/> and ran the club until 1999, until he closed the property to begin its redevelopment.<ref name="NYT1"/> The first general manager of the club, Chief Operating Officer [[Carolyn Kepcher]], later became co-host on Trump's television show ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]''.<ref name="Kepcher1"/> She was fired from the show and management position in August 2006.<ref name="Kepcher2"/>
On March 16, 1999, Briarcliff was operating its mayoral election, and incumbent mayor Keith Austin ran unopposed. Write-ins supporting lawyer Richard Mattiaccio prompted a conflict involving hundreds of residents, which led to one arrest. The event took place near the polls at the Village Hall; Mattiaccio had gained supporters by criticizing Austin's weak opposition to Trump's club reconstruction plans. Many residents believed a large project would congest streets with construction vehicles and rip up the landscape.<ref name="Controversy"/> In redesigning the club and its course, Trump hired golf course architect Jim Fazio, brother of [[Tom Fazio]] in the same profession.<ref name="Fazio"/> Around the same time, the workmen resodded a village soccer field and assisted in constructing a new veterans' memorial in Briarcliff.<ref name="NYT1"/> He also had the current {{convert|75000|sqft|adj=on}} white clapboard and fieldstone clubhouse<ref name="Rebuild"/> built on the property.<ref name="Value"/> At one time, due to residents' criticism, the clubhouse was reduced to {{convert|35000|sqft|adj=on}}, eliminating guest rooms and special event halls. It was designed by Robert Lamb Hart Planners & Architects, and included three stories with lockers, a 150-seat restaurant, and top-floor lounge.<ref name="Reduce"/><!--He demolished a {{convert|65000|sqft|adj=on}} clubhouse and replaced it with a {{convert|42000|sqft|adj=on}} one (originally planned at {{convert|81500|sqft|adj=on}})<ref name="Rebuild"/>--> Other difficulties with the club's plans arose; the village planning board recognized villager concerns over golf tournaments, membership requirements, and pesticide use. And at the time of the club's reconstruction, Trump had three other golf clubs planned, including one in Seven Springs, an area within three towns which would require approval from all three, and one in the French Hill section of Yorktown.<ref name="Rebuild"/> Trump later dropped all of the plans, calling Westchester County "the toughest place to build on the planet".<ref name="Rebuild"/>
===Reopening and further events=== The first head golf professional was Frank Graniero.<ref name="Ebsco1"/> The club's first nine holes opened on April 15, 2002, followed by the next nine on June 29, 2002. The club had a total cost of $30 million<ref name="MCMA"/> or $40 million,<ref name="OpenCost"/> and was claimed to be the largest excavation project in Westchester County's history, with about {{convert|3000000|cuyd|adj=on}} of earth moved. The thirteenth hole cost Trump $7 million, surrounded by an artificial {{convert|101|ft|adj=on}} black granite waterfall, which pumps {{convert|5000|usgal|l|-2}} a minute.<ref name="OpenCost"/><!--$15 million 45,000 square foot clubhouse.<ref name="MCMA"/>-->
In 2003 Trump tried to move the [[Sybase Classic]], a [[LPGA]] tournament, from [[Wykagyl Country Club]] to Trump's club for 2007; the Wykagyl lease would run out in that year. Briarcliff Manor's mayor Peter Chatsky was opposed to the plan; Trump attempted to persuade the mayor to talk to his wife, [[Jean Chatzky]], about the financial benefit of hosting the tournament, adding that village residents would be hired for the event. A Trump Organization vice president suggested donating some proceeds to the [[Briarcliff Manor Public Library]]'s then-proposed expansion or toward improving a village baseball field. The club's special-use permit with the village restricted the course to 300 people and banned large-scale tournaments from taking place there.<ref name="LPGA">{{cite news|last=Rojas|first=Marcela|title=Trump to Briarcliff: Don't be 'stupid'|newspaper=The Journal News|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/442536341/665F466BF4C74A8BPQ/19?accountid=40999|date=July 6, 2003|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref> The discussion between the Trump Organization and village government stopped that year, however in 2004, Trump submitted a new request to bring a LPGA or [[PGA Tour|PGA]] tournament to the club.<ref name="Tour2">{{cite news|last=Marchant|first=Robert|title=Trump wants golf event in village|newspaper=The Journal News|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/442647322/665F466BF4C74A8BPQ/2?accountid=40999|date=June 18, 2004|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref>
A storm in June 2011 caused public utilities including the Briarcliff library and Law Memorial Park's public pool and playing fields to be flooded. When Trump had renovated the course, his workers made unauthorized changes to its drainage system, which made the course look and play better for golfers. The alterations lowered the system's water capacity and thus raised water levels by about six feet. The Trump Organization met with the village over the issue, though it did not take corrective actions. After negotiations ended, the village billed the club $238,353. The Trump Organization blamed the flooding on a village drainage pipe which lacked a grate, and blamed the conflict on then-Briarcliff mayor William Vescio, who owns a company that previously came into conflict with Trump. Vescio denied the relation to the previous conflict and claimed that the flooding was caused by rocks and trees at washed down the hill from the golf club.<ref name="War">{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=David McKay|title=Trump at war with Briarcliff Manor|newspaper=The Journal News|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1712761478/665F466BF4C74A8BPQ/13?accountid=40999|date=September 17, 2015|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Flood"/>
When President Obama was in Westchester in 2014, his staff attempted to schedule visits to local golf clubs including Trump National, none of which wanted to close their courses for the president to play. Trump replied to [[NBC 4 New York]]'s report of the news with a widely circulated and publicized tweet—"If Obama resigns from office NOW, thereby doing a great service to the country—I will give him free lifetime golf at any one of my courses!"<ref name="Obama"/> In 2015, the club sued the town of [[Ossining (town), New York|Ossining]] to lower its worth from $13.5 million to $1.4 million in order to reduce property and school taxes; local residents complained because their own taxes would rise.<ref name="Value"/> In 2016, the club revised its claims to $9 million, closer to the 2014 town estimate of $14.3 million.<ref name="NewValue"/> In June 2017, Trump disclosed a value of the club at over $50 million, with $9.7 million in personal income in 2016.<ref name="Discl"/>
[[Daniel Scavino]], social media director for Trump's presidential campaign began working at Briar Hall Country Club as a caddie in 2009, while in high school. He was promoted several times, including to general manager of the club after Trump's purchase.<ref name="Scav1"/><ref name="Scav2"/> In December 2016, he was announced as Assistant to the President and Director of Social Media.<ref name="Scav3">{{cite news|last1=Rucker|first1=Philip|last2=Viebeck|first2=Elise|title=Trump hires Conway, Spicer and other loyalists for senior White House jobs|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/9f3c5692-c862-11e6-bf4b-2c064d32a4bf|date=December 22, 2016|accessdate=December 23, 2016}}</ref> Trump's candidacy for the [[2016 United States presidential election]] affected the club; [[Horace Greeley High School]] used the facility for its annual proms, which was protested by its students in late 2015 due to its connection to Trump as a political candidate.<ref name="Prom1"/> The location for the 2016 prom has yet to be changed by student decision.<ref name="Prom2"/> In the following year, it was reported that [[Pleasantville High School (New York)|Pleasantville High School]]'s graduating class was considering changing its prom venue from Trump's club as well.<ref name="PHS">{{cite news|title=Pleasantville students debate whether to hold prom at Trump golf course Pleasantville students debate whether to hold prom at Trump golf course|newspaper=News 12|url=http://hudsonvalley.news12.com/pleasantville-students-debate-whether-to-hold-prom-at-trump-golf-course-1.13083417|date=February 8, 2017|accessdate=February 15, 2017}}</ref> The graduating class voted, 97-44, to keep the venue.<ref name="PHS2">{{cite news|last=Barron|first=Sam|title=Pleasantville Seniors Vote To Keep Prom At Trump National In Briarcliff|newspaper=Briarcliff Daily Voice|url=http://briarcliff.dailyvoice.com/schools/pleasantville-seniors-vote-to-keep-prom-at-trump-national-in-briarcliff/700429/|date=February 17, 2017|accessdate=February 17, 2017}}</ref> On June 7, 2016, Trump gave his nomination victory speech at the clubhouse; he had just won the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|Republican primaries]].<ref name="Speech1">{{cite news|last=Deb|first=Sopan|title=Trump delivers restrained victory speech with teleprompter|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-delivers-restrained-victory-speech-with-teleprompter/|date=June 8, 2016|accessdate=September 16, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Speech2">{{cite news|last1=Parker|first1=Ashley|last2=Maggie|first2=Haberman|title=Donald Trump Softens His Tone, and the G.O.P. Hopes It Will Last|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/09/us/politics/donald-trump-campaign.html?_r=0|date=June 8, 2016|accessdate=September 19, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2016, during Trump's presidential campaign, his opponent [[Hillary Clinton]] released a campaign video of one of the club's architects. The architect, Andrew Tesoro, described his dealings with [[the Trump Organization]], where about a dozen employees met him at the finished clubhouse to negotiate reducing his fees. They pressured him into sending a reduced bill, of $50,000 instead of $140,000. After the organization failed to pay the bill, Tesoro met with Trump who convinced him to accept only $25,000 for his services. The [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Clinton campaign]] used the story as part of its effort to demonstrate that the Trump Organization harms small businesses.<ref name="Tesoro1">{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Susan|title=This Architect Says Trump Almost Destroyed His Business...|newspaper=[[Forbes]]|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestreptalks/2016/07/13/this-architect-says-trump-almost-destroyed-his-business-but-that-doesnt-mean-they-cant-get-coffee/#8465f9d6d9a8|date=July 13, 2016|accessdate=September 6, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Tesoro2">{{cite news|last=Frizell|first=Sam|title=How Hillary Clinton Is Hitting Donald Trump's Business Record on Two Fronts|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|url=http://time.com/4397159/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-business-record/|date=July 7, 2016|accessdate=September 6, 2016}}</ref> Later during Trump's campaign, in September 2016, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that a {{convert|6|ft|adj=on|spell=in}} painting of Trump may be on display at the club. Trump had purchased Michael Israel's work for $200,000 in 2007 through his charity, the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]]. According to IRS regulations, the painting would have to be used for a charitable purpose, or donated to a charity, however Melania Trump had planned to hang it in the club's boardroom or conference room, and the artist later stated he believed it was at the clubhouse. Although the painting was purchased at a charity auction, where half of the Trump Foundation's check went to the charity, in September 2016 an IRS director deemed Trump to have violated IRS rules and President [[Barack Obama]] publicly criticized Trump's purchase.<ref name="Painting">{{cite news|last=Fahrenthold|first=David A.|title=Trump bought a 6-foot-tall portrait of himself with charity money. We may have found it.|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/a-clue-to-the-whereabouts-of-the-6-foot-tall-portrait-of-donald-trump/2016/09/14/ae65db82-7a8f-11e6-ac8e-cf8e0dd91dc7_story.html|date=September 14, 2016|accessdate=September 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Current operations== In 2001, annual membership dues were stated to be $9,000 per member or $12,000 for a family, with an initial deposit of $250,000.<ref name="NYT1"/> Before the 2008 recession, initiation fees were $100,000 to $150,000. As of late 2015, initiation fees were down to $50,000. Around that time, many new members were reportedly not charged an initiation fee or were no longer required by the club to fully pay it within five years. Annual dues were $19,400 a year.<ref name="2015dues"/>
===Property=== The club is located on about {{convert|140|acre|ha|-1}} adjacent to Briarcliff Manor's central business district<ref name="CBD"/> and in a residential area near [[Pace University]]'s former [[Briarcliff College|Briarcliff campus]]<ref name="NearPace"/> off Pine Road.<ref name="Ebsco1"/> The property contains "The Residences at Trump National Golf Club", a series of sixteen attached townhouses ranging in size from {{convert|3100|-|3,400|sqft}} and which were designed by William Devereaux & Associates.<ref name="NYT1"/> Plans exist for an additional 71 condominiums; the site was approved for 87 home sites in 1987.<ref name="Condos"/> The club also includes a member restaurant, which serves [[Kobe beef]] burgers, tuna flown in daily from Honolulu, and [[Trump Ice]] bottled water.<ref name="Grill"/>
==Notable members== Current members include former Yankees manager [[Joe Torre]], and actors [[Jack Nicholson]] and [[Clint Eastwood]].<ref name="Notable1"/> Around 2003, members included [[Rudy Giuliani]], [[Jack Nicholson]], [[Hugh Grant]], [[George Steinbrenner]], and [[Regis Philbin]].<ref name="LPGA"/> Visiting players include [[Ron Howard]], [[Regis Philbin]], and [[Bobby Bonilla]], who came for the course's reopening in 2002, and professional golfer [[Nick Faldo]].<ref name="CoursesLAT"/> Other visitors include [[Michael Jordan]],<ref name="Visitors1"/> former [[New York City mayor]]s [[Michael Bloomberg]] and Rudy Giuliani, and [[Billy Crystal]], who joined Trump and members Bill Clinton and Joe Torre for the 2008 Joe Torre Safe at Home Foundation Golf Classic at the club.<ref name="Visitors2"/><ref name="Visitors3"/><!--[[Tom Brady]]<ref name="Grill"/>-->
Former US President [[Bill Clinton]] has been a member of the club since May 2003. Donald Trump has said that he bought the club partly "because he knew Bill Clinton would need a place to play". Part of the Clintons' gift for Bill's 65th birthday was a round of golf at Trump National with Hillary and Chelsea Clinton.<ref name="Digest">{{cite news|last=Weinman|first=Sam|title=Once upon a time, when Bill Clinton needed a golf haven, he turned to Donald Trump|newspaper=[[Golf Digest]]|url=http://www.golfdigest.com/story/once-upon-a-time-when-bill-clinton-needed-a-golf-haven-he-turned-to-donald-trump|date=November 4, 2016|accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
The golf club is [[Eric Trump]]'s home course. He raises about $3 million each year in an event there for [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]]. [[Mariano Rivera]], the [[New York Knicks]], and the [[New York Rangers|Rangers]] also run charity tournaments there.<ref name="KnRang"/> At one time, Donald Trump had scheduled to be there himself at least once a week.<ref name="CoursesLAT">{{cite news|last=Bonk|first=Thomas|title=He Trumps His Love of Game|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/422073381/665F466BF4C74A8BPQ/10?accountid=40999|date=June 3, 2004|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> Eric Trump and his foundation received scrutiny from the press in June 2017 after it was revealed that the foundation was funneling money to the Trump Organization through its charity tournaments, held at Trump National Golf Club Westchester and other sites.<ref name="Eric">{{cite news|last=Mangan|first=Dan|title=Trump Organization charged Eric Trump's cancer charity big bucks for golf events: Report|newspaper=CNBC|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/06/trump-organization-charged-eric-trumps-cancer-charity-golf-events.html|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> A few days later, New York Attorney General [[Eric Schneiderman]] was reported to be investigating Eric Trump's foundation and its events at the golf course.<ref name="Eric2">{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=David McKay|title=NY AG targets Eric Trump Foundation over Westchester fundraising|newspaper=The Journal News|url=http://www.lohud.com/story/news/2017/06/15/ny-ag-targets-eric-trump-foundation-over-westchester-fundraising/397005001/|date=June 15, 2017|accessdate=June 16, 2017}}</ref>
==In media== The club was shown on Trump's show ''The Apprentice'', in [[The Apprentice (U.S. season 1)|season one]]'s two-part finale for [[Bill Rancic]]'s last challenge<ref name="Appr1"/><ref name="AppEp1">{{Cite episode|title=Down to the Wire|episodelink=The Apprentice (U.S. season 1)#Week 13: "Down to The Wire"|series=The Apprentice|serieslink=The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|network=NBC|publication-place=The [[GE Building]], New York City|date=April 8, 2004|season=1|number=14}}</ref><ref name="AppEp1=2">{{Cite episode|title=Season Finale|episodelink=The Apprentice (U.S. season 1)#Week 13=4: "Season Finale"|series=The Apprentice|serieslink=The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|network=NBC|publication-place=The [[GE Building]], New York City|date=April 15, 2004|season=1|number=15}}</ref> and [[The Apprentice (U.S. season 10)|season 10]]'s two-part finale for Clint Robertson's.<ref name="Appr2"/>
